name: Presidente. –
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Friday, 10 July 2020.

name: Presidente. –
text: Following the conclusions of the extraordinary meeting of the European Council that took place from 17 to 21 July 2020, I decided, in agreement with the Conference of Presidents and in accordance with Rule 154(4) of the Rules of Procedure, to convene this extraordinary sitting, today at 9.30 a.m., so that Parliament can debate and express its position on the recovery plan and on the 2021-2027 multiannual financial framework.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the statements by the European Council and the Commission on the conclusions of the extraordinary meeting of the European Council of 17-21 July 2020 (2020/2732(SDR)).

name: Manfred Weber (PPE).
text: – Mr President, before we start with the debate on the outcome of the European Council, I want to bring one very urgent issue to the attention of plenary, and that is the situation in the Mediterranean Sea. We saw the military actions from the Turkish side, we also saw the decisions on the Hagia Sophia, which is an example of religious chauvinism that such a symbol and as a monument of peace and reconciliation is now changed. Those are actions from the Turkish side. I want to underline that this is not only a Greek–Turkish issue, it is not only a Cyprus–Turkish issue, it is a European–Turkish issue and that’s why the presence of President Michel and President von der Leyen, we want to underline that we have to give clear signals that we stand on the side of our citizens in Greece and in Cyprus. And I think we should keep the dialogue open, no doubt about this, but now it is the time to act, probably also to consider sanctions against Turkey. We have to act and we have to act now, I want to bring this to the attention of the plenary.

text: I call on those Members who are sitting in their seats to wear masks, as required by our provisions.

name: Charles Michel
text: President of the European Council. Mr President, four days and four nights! These were complex negotiations on very complex issues. We agreed on the recovery package and the European budget, and this moment, it's my conviction, is pivotal in European history. We acted fast and with urgency. In less than two months, we hammered out a deal of more than EUR 1.8 trillion and this response is massive. Compared to the size of its economy, Europe's response is greater than that of the United States or China. In fact, this agreement is a first in many ways. This is the first time in European history that you agreed to borrow collectively to finance expenditure. It's also the first time, the first time that our budgetary funds are connected to our climate ambition. And, it's the first time our budget will be directly linked to the rule of law. I am convinced that Europe is a force for action. Today I stand before you with that agreement in hand, endorsed by unanimity by all 27 leaders. Everyone had to give something in order to get something. It's a strong and ambitious deal for Europe, and for Europeans it is fair, balanced and ground-breaking. Why? Because it will boost our three common goals: convergence, resilience and transformation. On the recovery fund, first, the Next Generation EU is a one-off measure to address the impact of COVID-19 and I would like to stress that the total size of the recovery fund is EUR 750 billion. EUR 390 billion in grants, and EUR 360 billion in loans. And these funds will be targeted at the hardest hit regions and sectors. It targets of 30% of the MMF and the recovery fund to fight climate change and we will make sure the recovery fund money is well spent by ensuring it is backed by solid governance. On the budget, we decide to propose 1,074 million euros. I underline the commitment, the mobilization, the desire to succeed with these means, to continue efforts to reduce disparities at the European level, to strengthen convergence and to initiate transformation, which is so necessary and urgent. I am a good measure, on the question of the MFF , some of you will certainly have the opportunity to point out , the reductions in comparison to the Commission's proposal. I also want to bring nuance to the debate, to look at the starting point. The starting point is the money that is spent every year on each of the policies implemented by the European Union. When we compare with today, we see that CFP and recovery plan together, each time it is additional resources compared to the current situation, which are mobilised in different areas: in the digital field, in the field of Horizon Europe, in the field of Erasmus. Finally, we propose to set up a special reserve in relation to Brexit because we take into account the fact that with or without agreement, in any event, we will have to support the countries and sectors that will be more directly affected by the economic consequences of brexit.  I appreciate that there is a theme that is getting a lot of attention here, and he also mobilized some during the summit; it is the issue of rebates, these corrective measures. It is true that these rebates were maintained for one country, increased for four other countries, and it is true that this was part of the overall agreement, because there was this exceptional situation, the need to mobilize resources within the framework of the recovery plan. The political agreement has given rise to this part of decisions, which I also want to highlight. I now turn to the issue of own resources. We have had a lot of formal and informal debates with this House, in relation to this very central issue, because we consider that own resources can represent a turning point in the way Europe sees its future, and for which, I think I can say, we have made progress perhaps even beyond what was conceivable just a few weeks ago. , by specifying a political timetable and, above all, I want to highlight it, by making an additional point in relation to the Commission's original proposal: this idea that we are going to start the repayment under the coming MFF and not under the next, which is an extremely politically powerful way to encourage decision-making. This engages us and I hope that parliament will be engaged. It will also engage heads of state and government. I think there is there, whether it is on the issue of carbon measures at borders, on the digital question, on financial transactions, on the question of the ETS system or on the issue of plastic waste, there will be material for democratic debate, political debate in the noble sense of the word, within the framework of democracy certainly within the framework of national parliaments, and that is a good thing. For, beyond this debate, it is central questions about the direction we want for the European Union that will be asked. Secondly, the question of the role of the European Parliament, which is, of course, an essential question. I can see that it will most certainly be debated here, beyond what is already provided for in the institutional framework and the role of Parliament in the legislative work and therefore the role for the centrepiece, which is the SRR, the Recovery and Resilience Fund. For other expenditure programmes, this is paragraph 11 of our conclusions, we have proposed that there be a joint sharing of political control, the Council and the European Parliament, within the framework of the annual expenditure control, and I have no doubt that we will prolong discussions on this subject. Finally, I want to highlight a point that is close to my heart, one that must be close to our hearts. I have been in charge of sitting in the European Council for five years now, first as Belgian Prime Minister, now in the capacity of President of the European Council. And for the first time in five years, this weekend we had a very long debate around the table, the 27 heads of state and government, eyes in the eye, on the question of the rule of law, of fundamental values. The debate that we have had must be not a culmination point, but a step, an important step, a useful step, and it is in this that I am pleased that what is presented to you inscribes this link, this conditionality, between the financial question and the question of governance, the question of the rule of law. Everyone will have to play their part: the Commission, of course, within the framework of the institutions; The European Parliament; but also the European Council, which, in the context of the responsibility of leading the political policy debate, will also not escape the need to return regularly to this subject. I will ensure that this central theme, this vital theme, fundamental to the European agenda, remains at the centre of the democratic debate. Ladies and gentlemen, I conclude by saying this: a few days ago we had rocked more than 600,000 deaths worldwide, linked to Covid-19. The Covid-19 shoved us, the Covid-19 shook us. It shook up the way our democratic societies operated. We had to come to terms with what was unthinkable a few months ago: drastically restricting personal freedoms, fundamental freedoms, putting the health system to the test terribly. I am totally convinced of this: the world after the Covid-19 must be different, it must be more engaged, stronger and more rooted in this demand for humanity that brings us all together. The agreement I am presenting to you today is, in my view, an agreement which, of course, deals with financial matters, but it is much more than that, in reality. It is much more than that because, through the debate that is now open, it is the meaning, the direction we want to give for the next few years to this European project that is on the agenda. I think this moment is historic, and I will show a hint of romanticism. I believe that by this extraordinary decision, to decide that we were going to mobilise a strong agenda for own resources, to decide that we were going to borrow together to invest and to reform, in a way, what we have done is to renew our marriage vows at European level for 30 years. It is European unity that has been affirmed and, more than ever, I think that what we are sending as a signal to the Europeans is a signal of confidence, robustness and solidity. The signal we are sending to the rest of the world is that Europe is there, Europe is strong, Europe is standing.

name: Ursula von der Leyen
text: Présidente de la Commission. – Six cent mille... Six cent mille victimes de ce virus tueur! Six cent mille vies achevées trop tôt! Six cent mille histoires écrites à moitié seulement! 600 000 familles aujourd'hui incomplètes! Ces six cent mille personnes resteront toujours présentes dans nos mémoires et dans nos cœurs. Et nous savons que ce n'est pas fini, malheureusement. Pas encore...  Derrière ce triste cortège, nous voyons le terrible impact sur notre économie. Nos citoyens, nos travailleurs, nos entreprises, tout le monde souffre et tout le monde se bat. Cette pandémie nous a frappés au début de l'année, et souvenons-nous de ces jours, de ces courbes de malades qui montaient, du nombre de morts qui grimpait, des divisions entre nos pays qui menaçaient! Nous avons entendu des critiques blessantes, des mots qui divisaient le Nord et le Sud, l'Est et l'Ouest, des débats sur les «obligations corona» qui finissaient par des poings serrés et des doigts pointés. La situation était sombre et les options peu nombreuses. Et les rares solutions mises sur la table étaient intergouvernementales, c'est-à-dire hors du cadre européen, sans méthode communautaire, sans Parlement européen et, je le rappelle, nous étions également sans accord sur notre budget européen, deux ans après notre proposition! C'est pour cela que la Commission européenne a fait une proposition européenne pour éviter les réflexes et les erreurs du passé. Une proposition européenne pour une relance européenne. We all know that Europe is not out of the woods yet. But Europe can see now dawn turning into light.  This week, not only taboos and perceptions have been cast aside, but one big watershed for our Union has been crossed.  By standing united – 27 Member States backing the Commission – we raise money on the capital market to fight the worst economic crisis ever – together.  In Next Generation EU, we now have a unique recovery tool worth EUR 750 billion. EUR 750 billion to support the hardest hit. EUR 750 billion to boost our Single Market. EUR 750 billion to invest in the European Green Deal, in digitisation and the modernisation of our single market and resilience.  Of course, 27 countries agreeing something on this scale – and of this unique nature – is a challenge. It takes courage, political will and, of course, give and take. It was never going to be easy. But, anything worth having is always worth fighting for! And I thank you, Charles, for the excellent cooperation and the trustworthy management – thank you very much for that.  And look at how far Europe’s fighting spirit has taken us. It is not long ago that some asked for no grants – loans only. But today we have an agreement that Next Generation EU will have EUR 390 billion in grants, topped by EUR 360 billion in loans. And yes, there are fewer grants than the Commission and the Parliament argued for, but from where we started, this is an enormous achievement.  And this is big enough to make an enormous difference.  It will invest in reforms linked to our European priorities, in line with our country-specific recommendations. And, because this is a European investment in our European Union, it is essential that the European Parliament plays a key role. As co-legislator, this House will have its full say on the design of the Facility and how it works.  The Commission will ensure full transparency, including through standing ready for a structured dialogue on priorities and expenditure, and a regular exchange of views on national plans and overall implementation. And this is how, together, we can ensure that Next Generation EU delivers where it really matters. This is also how we can ensure that Next Generation EU accelerates the twin green and digital transformation. 30% of Next Generation EU and our MFF will be spent on climate-related projects and, if we get it right, I believe that Next Generation EU can be one of the largest stimulus for investment and reforms anywhere in the world – investing in the rollout of 5G, grid infrastructure, in AI and industrial digitisation, in renewables, sustainable transport, energy-efficient buildings, you name it! This is how we fight climate change and modernise.  This stimulus will also support much needed structural reforms to make us more resilient. And, we will have a Just Transition Fund to support those people, those regions and sectors who have indeed a bigger step to take.  As you know, I would have liked more. But this week’s agreement ensures a 125% increase in the size of the Just Transition Fund – now worth EUR 17.5 billion – and that will make a real difference on the ground.  The big winner of this summit are the new own resources. We have now a unanimous agreement on the need for new own resources. We have a clear timetable and we have them linked to repayment. This is a huge and historic step forward for our Union, which both the Commission and the Parliament have long being pushing for.  Now we have no time to waste. The Commission will come forward with a package of new own resources. This will include a digital levy. We will also put forward a carbon border adjustment mechanism and an extension of the Emission Trading System. The two go hand in hand.  We need to put a price on carbon in all key sectors of the economy at home and we need to avoid carbon leakage from elsewhere to make sure that we are sustainable and competitive.  Allow me to come to another issue, which is at the heart of what our Union is all about: our values. These values – including the respect for the rule of law – are the very foundation of our Union. These values they are mandatory and they are priceless.  The European Council has stated a clear commitment in respecting the rule of law and protecting our financial interests. And I not only strongly welcome this – also because it is of utmost importance with even more public money on the table than ever before with Next Generation EU – but against this background, the Commission will now follow up. We will look into our 2018 proposal on the rule of law. We will work together with the co-legislators to ensure that our 2018 proposal is taken forward and where necessary, improved. Protecting our budget and the respect for the rule of law, go hand in hand. And we must also do everything we can to protect European money by stepping up the fight against fraud. This means having the right controls in place, including a database that puts us in the position to know who the final beneficiaries of EU funding are, and we will work closely with the Parliament to make this happen in the next weeks and months.  I started by saying that the European Council’s agreement provided the light at the end of the tunnel. But with light also comes shadow. And in this case, the shadow is in the form of a very lean long-term EU budget. There are regrettable and painful decisions on many programmes, which have crucial European added value. I am thinking of Horizon, our essential Health Programme, of InvestEU. Yes, all these have been increased, but certainly not as much as we would have liked. And I believe the size of our external funds, in particular, is really concerning and we should always remember that the value of EU programmes far outweigh their costs.  Yes, we managed to avoid even further cuts – as some Member States wanted – but this MFF is a difficult pill to swallow and I know this House feels the same way. (Applause) And here again, we should also take a step back and look at where we are coming from. Before we even started, this budget had a hole of around EUR 70 billion because of Brexit, with one big Member State less contributing. The good news is that we have managed to plug almost all of that gap. That means that every country has to pay more. And when you put Next Generation EU on top, we now have a massive and unprecedented financial firepower of EUR 1.8 trillion. That is almost 13% of our EU 27 GNI. And then, MFF and Next Generation EU together, will increase the percentage of modern policies to over 50%. Just look around the world to see who else can say the same as us.  Meine Damen und Herren! Wir haben jetzt die Chance, gemeinsam etwas Historisches für Europa zu erreichen. Der Druck der Krise hat Türen geöffnet, die ganz, ganz lange verschlossen waren. So traurig der Anlass, es ist auch eine neue Chance für Europa, für unsere Gemeinschaft. Vor zehn Jahren, in der Finanz- und Eurokrise, haben wir zwar die Union und den Euro vor dem Auseinanderbrechen bewahrt, aber der innere Preis war gigantisch: Unsere Volkswirtschaften haben sich gegenläufig entwickelt. Junge Menschen mussten auf der Suche nach Arbeit und Zukunft ihre Heimat verlassen, Schuldzuweisungen zwischen Staaten wuchsen, und die Risse sind bis heute sichtbar und spürbar. Dieses Mal machen wir vieles anders und, wie ich glaube, manches besser. 750 Milliarden Euro – der überwiegende Teil als Zuschuss – sind ein großartiges Signal der Solidarität und der Reformbereitschaft. Aber Next Generation EU bedeutet viel, viel mehr als Geld. In vergangenen Krisen umgingen die Mitgliedstaaten die europäischen Institutionen – auch aus Misstrauen. Das bedeutete damals null Mitsprache und null Gestaltungsmacht für das Europäische Parlament.  Dieses Mal ist es anders. Dieses Mal setzen wir auf eine gemeinschaftliche Lösung, auch weil die Kommission sich aktiv dafür eingesetzt hat und mit einem klugen Vorschlag überzeugt hat. Dank Next Generation EU sind alle Mitgliedstaaten gleichermaßen in der Lage, in der Krise ihren Menschen, ihren Unternehmen zu helfen, ohne dass den öffentlichen Haushalten die Luft zum Atmen abgeschnürt wird. Und auch weil Next Generation EU auf der Gemeinschaftsmethode basiert, wird es Wunden heilen und uns zusammenbringen. Dieses Mal legen wir die Verantwortung für das Schicksal Europas und die Zukunftschancen unserer Kinder auf unser aller breite Schultern. Das ist eine Last, die wir gemeinsam mit Verantwortungsbereitschaft und mit Stolz tragen. Lang lebe Europa! Long live Europe! Vive l'Europe! (Beifall)

name: Manfred Weber
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, solidarity is coming home; that is the main message of the outcome of the Council meeting. In these last few days, we have also seen the alternative: a possible horror scenario of nationalism and egoism. We, as the EPP, are very happy now that the European Council is sending a clear signal of togetherness. Nowhere else in the world except for these 27 countries is giving such a strong and united response to the COVID-19 crisis. That’s why I want to thank Charles Michel, Ursula von der Leyen, Angela Merkel and our president for the negotiations. There were a lot of sleepless nights, but finally a good outcome was reached. You did a great job in holding Europe together, and the EPP Group supports the spirit of solidarity and togetherness. I’m happy about the agreement – no doubt about that – but I’m not happy about the deal. While we welcome the outcome of the Council meeting, we are living in a parliamentary democracy, and that means that the outcome is now arriving here in the European Parliament. The rule all over Europe is that the output after a parliamentary consultation will never be the same as the input from the Council side. That is now ahead of us. This means we must not delay things, because I hear these arguments now around the corridors. The first MFF proposal – Ursula von der Leyen referred to this – was on the table of the Council in 2018, so don’t tell us about delaying things, there was a lot of time to do the job. (Applause) That’s why what we are doing now is the normal consent procedure based on the Lisbon Treaty. And yes, there are a lot of points where we have to criticise and, Ursula, we are for the moment not ready to swallow the bitter pill you referred to, namely the MFF. On the MFF, we think that it doesn’t provide proper answers to the challenges of the next seven years. It has to be more future-orientated, and I, as an elected Member of Parliament, also refer again to the promises I made to my voters. The EPP promised, for example, a strong and effective coastal and border guard, and now there is not enough money to do this. The EPP promised that Europe would tackle the big diseases such as cancer together, and now there are dramatic cuts in the health budget in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic, which is unbelievable. The EPP promised a strong boost for European innovation once the European Council formulated the 3% target to finance innovation. We are losing ground to China and Asia on innovation, we are losing our future and now there are cuts to Horizon Europe. The EPP promised a strong Europe in the world, and now defence, Africa, neighbourhood are being cut. That is the first point we have to talk about. The second point is Europe is not a cash machine for national budgets. The proposal on the table brings us to the renationalisation of European money and of the European budget. 90 % of the EUR 750 billion in the Next Generation EU fund will go directly to the Member States’ budgets. So far, nobody knows exactly what this money will be spent on. Each leader came back home in the last days with a nice envelope of money, but will there really be a European spirit when we now spend the money? My fear is that this will be spent here and there purely on national favourites. The French Finance Minister said already that they will use it for social projects, in other countries they will build motorways, and in other countries they will lower their taxes to create growth. That is the reality when we see the debate Europe—wide. In a couple of months, we will sit here again together in the European Parliament and complain that the citizens don’t understand what the purpose of European money is or what the idea of European money is; we will complain that the people don’t see the added value of Europe. That is the drama we will face if, again, we don’t use this money for clear European projects like our predecessors did, for example, with Airbus. That’s why we think that the Member States, the Council, should have agreed on, for example, a real 5G transnational network, on an EU battery project, and on a plan for EU hydrogen where each Member State is using their own envelope for these investments. Citizens can now count on the European Parliament not to give up on this idea. We want to have a say on what the EU money will be spent on and we will be the watchdog on the European added value. I ask President Michel and President von der Leyen to formally propose a list of five, six or seven EU industrial innovation projects that each and every Member State would commit to contributing to finance through the Recovery Fund resources they will receive in the next upcoming months and years. Thirdly, we have to speak about rule of law again. The first time we link European money to a binding rule of law mechanism is a positive step, but when I see today the statements of our leaders, then I’m a little bit confused. Macron says that money will be only spent while respecting rule of law and others say there is no link. That’s why, Ursula, we have to be clear on this. We need a roadmap, we need a clear plan for implementing the principle: no money without respecting the European rules and the European mechanisms. (Applause) And then, we are ready, I want to thank again for the outcome. After the European Council, we have to work hard now for a good and quick solution. Let’s use now the time ahead of us to find a solution and to improve the deal. We are ready to do so. (Applause)

name: Iratxe García Pérez
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr. President, President Michel, President Von der Leyen, will allow me to begin with a few words that Aroa López, nurse at Vall d'Hebron hospital, delivered last week at the state funeral in Spain in memory of the victims of COVID-19: "We have given everything we had, we have worked to the limit of our forces and we have re-understood , better than ever, why we choose this profession: caring for and saving lives; although many companions had to give their own lives for it. We have covered the basic and emotional needs, we have been messengers of the last goodbye for elderly people who died alone, listening to the voices of their children over the phone. We've made video calls, shake hands and had to swallow a lot of tears."  It's a time when we face the worst crisis of our generation. The European Union could not leave the current and future generations behind. The agreement reached in the Council, Mrs Von der Leyen, Mr Michel, will go to the annals of European construction. For the first time in the history of the Union, the Member States have agreed to the issuance of joint debt, which is something unthinkable just over three months ago, and I would like to remind you that it was this Parliament that made that proposal. We must be proud as an institution.  The rejection of decisions unanimously in the governance of Eurobonds is another milestone that accelerates the European Union's federal impass. For decades, individual vetoes have shown their darker face with the paralysis of Community life and we now have, with the Conference on the Future of Europe, an opportunity to also try to choose a new way of making decisions in the European project. Thanks to its commitment, the European Union demonstrates learning from the mistakes of the 2008 crisis. If the austerity policy decided to save the banks and leave people behind, now people will be our priority. And if we want them to come first, we must focus our efforts on the transformations needed to achieve a greener, fairer, more digital society. The Social Democrats will not allow the recovery to fall on the shoulders of the most vulnerable. To this end, we will require a roadmap with binding commitments on new own resources that do not strangle the accounts of national budgets or the purchasing power of taxpayers.  We're only going to get out of this crisis with a fair taxation. Because it is unacceptable that the tax systems of certain States allow multinationals to save millions and millions of euros to the detriment of our welfare state.  There's no time to waste. The virus continues to hit and this Parliament must ensure that recovery is put in place as soon as possible. And, as a budgetary authority, Parliament will negotiate on an equal footing with the Council. Also for the implementation of the recovery fund and the approval of the next budget period. While we are aware of the historical significance of the recovery fund, we do not share the same optimism with the proposed financial framework for the coming years. The Social Democrats will not accept cuts to the long-term objectives at a time like the one we are living in, where we need to strengthen our strategic autonomy and reduce the differences between states.  We will work on the negotiations, which we hope will begin as soon as possible, to increase funding for programmes such as Horizon 2020, InvestEU, LIFE, Erasmus, Digital Europe, as well as areas of development cooperation and humanitarian aid. Because our recovery cannot be at the cost of leaving those who need it most abandoned and still live in worse conditions than we do. Solidarity within Europe, but also outside our borders.  And we will remain very firm against any proposal that jeopardizes the rule of law we have decided to build. The rights and freedoms of the Union are mandatory. The Socialists are clear. Not a single euro for those Governments that do not act with full respect for the rule of law and the fundamental values of the Union. Colleagues, when politics ceases to be useful to people, society stops relying on politics. And, therefore, it is now the moment of capitalized policy, which he agrees on, of which he commits, of which he is able to leave particular interests for the sake of a common interest. That's the moment we have to defend.  Yesterday i was told by a young man on social media: "I have once again trusted that another Europe is possible." We've got it in our hands, let's commit to it. For Europe, for citizens and for citizens, another Europe is possible.

name: Dacian Cioloş
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Madam President, Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate the President of the European Council, Charles Michel, for his determination to forge a compromise and, above all, Charles, for cultivating a relationship of trust with the European Parliament, which is essential for what we must do together - we must say so. In just a few weeks, Europe has managed to show unprecedented solidarity; we are setting up a common loan, which we will have to repay together, to respond to one of the worst crises ever. My group, Renew Europe, has made this recovery plan its workhorse since April and May. We are glad to see that it is now in place, because today it is becoming a reality. But the historical dimension - because it is indeed a historical dimension - of this agreement in the Council should not prevent us from comparing what is on the table with our own ambitions for Europe and our own ambitions for the euro: the Council prefers to give priority to the European Fund to finance more national programmes at the expense of the Union's programmes. This logic favourable to national interests should not undermine our ability to develop a truly European investment strategy. This programme, this European debt which we will have to pay back together, does not make sense if we do not finance real European projects. And that is the task of this Parliament.  National programmes will have to integrate these European priorities and Parliament must give itself the means to ensure this through an inter-institutional agreement on the implementation of this programme. For agreement to be reached, we need a multi-year financial framework with sufficient resources to finance our policies for the future: digital, research, youth and Erasmus, the health programme, in crisis but which is essential - this is one of the lessons to be learned from this crisis - cannot be sacrificed on the altar of the return rate for the Member States. There also needs to be a clear commitment to own resources, it would simply not be serious to borrow that amount without really knowing how we are going to repay it. It is essential to have a clear inter-institutional commitment to adopt these new own resources before the start of repayment of stimulus loans, and that is our condition: this very precise timetable must be adopted before we start repaying this debt.  Finally, my group will sign its final agreement if, and only if, the package contains strong guarantees as to the ability to link the European Fund to respect for the rule of law; guarantees that are not declarative, but practical and implemented. That is the only way to believe that this time we are really going to get to this mechanism.  We need a new system with clear rules neither against Hungary nor against Poland or against any other Member State in particular, but to ensure that European money no longer funds politicians in power who turn their backs on our fundamental values every day.  Mr President, this European Council has once again demonstrated that the European project cannot be limited to the sum of national interests, where everyone vetoes it. Our futures are common, as are our challenges, our failures, our successes.  The conference on the future of Europe must become an opportunity to redefine governance and put the interests of Europeans first with the sole aim of bringing the magic of the European project to life, as you have said.

name: Nicolas Bay
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, a historic day for Europe, said French President Emmanuel Macron. But big words cannot erase great failures or big forfeitures. In the joint resolution presented today by all groups from the centre-right to the extreme left, it deplores the lack of cases that the Council makes of the European Parliament. The haste of our Assembly to meet within 48 hours and finally greet obediently, with a few simple reservations, the agreement negotiated a few days ago, contribute to relegating our Parliament to a role of figuration and recording chamber. Parliamentary and legislative work, in order to be respected as such, to be credible, still requires a minimum of time and serenity. If you are running out of time today, it is first of all because we lost a lot of time yesterday: firstly because the European institutions were the main absentees from the health crisis themselves; the crisis should have been an opportunity to re-found the European Union on sound foundations, localism, economic protections, free cooperation between nations, industrial independence, the end of bureaucracy. This crucial turning point for Europe, it was missed by sin of hubris, of excess, Brussels wanted to do what it always does: go even further, even faster, continue its flight forward without ever acknowledging its mistakes or learning from it. Absent in the anticipation of the crisis and absent in the coordination of European countries in the face of the crisis, the Union is now trying to forget its failures and shortcomings by presenting, in a triumphalist way, a recovery plan negotiated in pain of which so few European countries will really be the beneficiaries. 92 hours of painstaking negotiations have shown that national interests will always take over the federal utopia. Yes, Mr Macron, yes, Mrs Merkel, nations, they still exist. Most of the boastful announcements were finally evacuated or planed, direct aid to the economy went from 500 billion to less than 400 billion at the end of the first round of the table and in the process the funds of the common agricultural policy, research, or Erasmus were cut. But the main objective - dogmatic, ideological - it remains: to take another step towards the European centralised state through continental debt pooling. The question is what is the gain for our nations, what is the real benefit to our peoples?  These economic supports could well have been organised by each country, with the advantage of deciding on the use of this money instead of being dictated to by the Commission. To make the pill swallow, we are now told, in a mixture of bad faith and candour, that this colossal debt, admittedly incurred by the Commission but which is due by the nations, would be repaid thanks to the famous own resources, the first step towards a European tax eagerly desired by some. A carbon tax, a GAFAM tax, a plastic tax whose introduction remains very hypothetical and financial products totally unknown. In practice, as always, it is the 9 net contributors to the European budget that will have to bear the burden of this new debt tomorrow. Thus, for example, France will have 40 billion euros out of 750 and will see its contribution to the budget increase for the next 6 years. What is historic, to use Macron's term, is probably to see a president negotiate a deal against the interests of his own country. The health crisis must not become the new pretext for continuing to build the European Union not only without the peoples, but against their fundamental interests.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, their name is Mark Rutte, a Dutch liberal, Sebastian Kurz, an Austrian Christian Democrat, Mette Fredriksen, Sanna Marin and Stefan Lefven, a Scandinavian socialist. They like to call themselves "frugals"; I would say "radins." For them, the European Union is a money pump that their country always feeds too much. In the face of this unprecedented crisis, it should at most act as an intermediary between a few ailed Member States and financial markets. They do not see that by doing so, tensions within the monetary union would be triggered by tensions that could be fatal to it. However, if they were honest, the stingers would explain to their fellow citizens how much their country has benefited - and still benefits - from European economic integration, and that it is therefore right that their contribution to the European budget should be equal to these benefits. But, very cynically, they prefer to keep the butter of the internal market without paying the right price.  Their name is Viktor Orban, a Hungarian Christian Democrat, or Tadeusz Morawiecki, a Polish conservative. They are often referred to as "illiberals"; I would say "pseudo-democrats." For them, the European Union is a money pump for the benefit of their country, their oligarchs, even themselves. But if they were honest, the pseudo-democrats would explain to their fellow citizens how much their country has benefited - and still benefits - from European integration, and that respecting the commitments made when they joined, starting with that of the rule of law and freedoms, is only the right consideration for solidarity. Very cynically, however, they prefer to take the money from the butter by demanding the creamer's smile as a bonus. Unlike these, a majority of heads of state and government have fortunately grasped the gravity of the moment. Two hundred thousand Europeans have already been swept away by the pandemic and the impact of the pandemic has caused inequality in Europe to explode. It strikes us at a time when time is running out to meet the climate challenge and when, in the face of Xi Jinping's China, Trump's United States, Putin's Russia or Erdogan's Turkey, the European Union feels very alone in defending freedom, the rule of law and a world order based on negotiated rules. But the twenty-seven heads of state or government had to decide unanimously, which put them at the mercy of the most extremist among them. The von der Leyen Commission's proposals to respond to the pandemic have come out mutilated: their amount, already insufficient, has been cut by almost a quarter, and these amputations affect, as Charles Michel pointed out, first of all the joint initiatives carried out and the most promising for the future. And once again, while the need for public investment has never been more acute, the European budget is once again being reduced, particularly in its dimensions linked to the Green Pact. For example, the Rural Development Fund, the greenest component of the Common Agricultural Policy, is being slashed in half. And how can we conceive, at a time when the world is worried about a second wave of contamination, that European leaders are drastically cutting into research and public health programmes? The icing on the cake: the stingers have managed to contribute even less to these investments than in the past. On the positive side, we are pleased that the target of spending 30% of Eu spending on combating climate change has been adopted. But beware, without truly restrictive enforcement and control mechanisms, the risk is that make-up will prevail over reality. On the respect of the rule of law by the beneficiaries, I welcome the discussion to which you have alluded, Mr President, but the mechanism adopted remains unclear, and there is no guarantee that it will be effective.  Despite all this, thanks to the perseverance of Angela Merkel and Charles Michel, the essential element of the architecture proposed by the Commission remains: for the first time, the European Union will finance massive investments with a common loan. The question of their reimbursement, and this is another blind spot at the top, remains largely unresolved. In our view, it will finally be necessary, yes, Mr Bay, for the Member States to grant the Union the right to raise taxes, in particular on those predators that have become multinational companies (not just those of digital) and on polluting activities. If such own resources were to be adopted, we would be in the presence of a prototype - albeit limited in time and scope - of this budgetary union without which the European Union is condemned to insignificance. That's why, beyond the unglamorous events of the last few days, it is absolutely crucial that the implementation of this plan is likely to restore this essential ingredient for the future of the Union: trust. For its part, the European Parliament will fully assume its responsibilities as budgetary authority. Seizing the hand extended by the Council and the Commission, my colleagues and I are ready to enter into negotiations until a satisfactory agreement is reached, both in terms of volume and on the direction of expenditure and on their governance and conditionality, with the compass, and you have heard it from colleagues, the general European interest. Before concluding, Mr President, I would like to address once again the stingy and pseudo-democrats. Through their speeches and actions, which reduce the European Union to a financial abyss or a new avatar of the Soviet Union, they instill day after day, year after year, the poison of nationalism among their fellow citizens; they pit European citizens against each other. Before them, the British Conservatives have taken this path, and we all know where it leads. On the contrary, rather than turning our backs, we Europeans need more than ever to stick together to ensure that everyone, present and future, is able to live a life worth living. It is together that we will find the intelligence and the strength to chart our path in the twenty-first century. This is our struggle, and we will never abandon it.

name: Presidente. –
text: Before continuing with the debate, I must proceed to the opening of the first round of voting. We shall proceed to the vote on the amendments to the motion for a resolution on the conclusions of the extraordinary European Council. Voting time will be from 10.30 a.m. to 11.45 a.m. The method is the one used in recent part-sessions. I declare the first voting time open. You have until 11.45 am and we will have the results at 1.30 pm.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the continuation of the debate on the Statements by the European Council and the Commission on the conclusions of the extraordinary meeting of the European Council of 17-21 July 2020 (2020/2732(SDR)).

name: Roberts Zīle
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, honourable Presidents of the Council and the Commission, ahead of the European Council, the ECR Group had a clear message: it was time to act. Although it took many days, the European Council did it. They were not easy decisions – taking many days of negotiations – and the result contains compromises and requires significant flexibility. But overall, the outcome shows that the mutual respect for all nation states allows to bring us to a reasonable deal or an agreement or some kind of process, like Manfred Weber described, which allows us to move forward. There are others in this House who disagree. Citizens across Europe look first and foremost to their national governments to provide a response to the pandemic. While we stand together in solidarity, the ECR Group considers it right that national governments are empowered to directly respond and swiftly deliver necessary support. As Member States decide what kind of measures should be taken to safeguard the citizens during the pandemic, governments also have to deliver in the best way using solidarity resources, of course, with scrutiny. At the same time, we have to remember that the most important thing is to give back to our people their hopes, jobs and incomes for them to survive and to have a good future. Well, the marathon summit and the conclusions is not the end of the road, and we as a group see clear issues to be resolved. Concerning the funds, they will not immediately be available to those countries and communities most affected by coronavirus. The ECR Group struggles to accept that funds would not be available until 12 months or more after the darkest periods of pandemic experienced so far across many Member States. There is a clear risk that in responding to this crisis, we risk delaying, and it would be a dangerous moment and a response from citizens. We stand ready to make the necessary improvements by engaging in a constructive manner to finalise the agreement as soon as possible. There are areas in the MFF, particularly, where we can do better. We regret the cuts to agriculture and regional development, turning money away from economic development and other key goals. Reductions to other significant programmes, including resources to deliver on the Digital Agenda, a competitive single market, there is strong focus on employment, and the geopolitical agenda risks leaving Europe ill—equipped to deal with the challenges arising from its global competitors.  And finally, we must, therefore, still enter into negotiations on the MFF where the role of Parliament is clear. It will be not easy; we are divided by Member States, by political views, but I think we don’t need to delay this procedure and to finalise, as best as possible in these circumstances, a deal.

name: Martin Schirdewan
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Mrs von der Leyen, Mr Michel, I would like to thank mrs von der Leyen for her work and for the work she has said. It will come as no surprise to you that I am not particularly enthusiastic about your hymns of praise. After a long back and forth, the Member States have finally been able to agree on a building fund for which the Commission will take on common debt – so far, so good. Europe has had to wait a very long time for this signal of solidarity, albeit a modest one. My group's position has always been clear: the EU is called upon to provide a comprehensive response to the Corona crisis and to ensure social and economic recovery and to link it to the socially digital and socio-ecological transformation of our continent. If this outcome of the European Council is measured against this ambition, it is simply disappointing. Instead of an ambitious development plan, we are now getting an instrument that not only falls far short of what is needed in terms of volume in order to cope with an economic downturn of up to 10% of Europe's gross domestic product, but also continues to rely on the wrong policy of saving and cutting, thereby continuing to stifle investment and domestic demand in a completely counterproductive way. This Council meeting lacked a mindset that could have marked the start of a new European project; national egoisms. This is also reflected in the fact that the Council has not been able to agree on an explicit rule of law mechanism. The free press, an independent judiciary, equality between women and men, trade union organisation are not goods that can be messed up for a few billion, but foundations in a democracy. Repaying the debt through own resources is, in principle, a good idea, Mrs von der Leyen, but this alone will not work with the plastic tax that has been specifically planned so far: 3 billion a year in estimated revenue, 390 billion grants, which makes a repayment period of 130 years. Social solidarity also means tax justice, and that is why we now need a digital tax with an estimated annual revenue of EUR 8 billion, a financial transaction tax with an estimated revenue of EUR 57 billion per year and a wealth levy for super-rich companies. The super-rich have to play their part in the build-up, and there you will also find the additional funds that you have talked about, Mrs von der Leyen. Incidentally, Mr Michel, instead of being shown by the tax haven of the Netherlands – and this goes to everyone here – tax havens in the EU should finally be closed. The multiannual financial framework is also not ambitious enough and falls far short of the demands and positions that have often been articulated in this House. More investment is needed in the future. It is not credible to save precisely there – for example, in terms of funding for digitization, health protection, or the Just Transition Fund – to set the red pencil there, and at the same time to increase military spending and investment in weapons systems. Europe missed a chance last weekend. I'm not sure it's going to get a second of its kind.

name: Dino Giarrusso (NI).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today is an historic day for all European citizens: we are voting for an important change, which we had been waiting for decades for in relation to policies that Europe had pursued with short-sightedness, disappointing, penalising and impoverishing millions of its citizens. As an Italian and as a European, I thank President Giuseppe Conte for the excellent result achieved at the European Council and my colleagues in the 5 Star Movement for the synergy created with him and the valuable work done. Next Generation EU must mean enough, forever, to austerity policies that have impoverished those who were worse off and created de facto discrimination between citizens of different states and different censuses. We turn the page and we have to turn it all the way. So beware of the cuts in the programmes, which we hope to correct. This change cannot only concern the post-COVID emergency, but must be the paradigm of the Europe to come: sharing risks and critical issues, solidarity between peoples, genuine growth and care for the environment. Let us therefore commit ourselves to keeping the promises made today, without ever going back, respecting the spirit of the founding fathers, without which Europe would have no reason to exist.

name: Siegfried Mureşan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the microphone wants me to thank you three times, I can gladly do this. President von der Leyen, President Michel, we welcome the agreement reached on the recovery package. And the message from the European Parliament is clear: we welcome the ambitious support of EUR 750 billion. Help is coming for the people affected by the coronavirus, for the enterprises affected and for the regions affected by this virus. Now it is very important that we get this right, that money is being used to modernise, to further develop the European Union and one thing is clear: the more we spend the better the control needs to be. Democratic and parliamentary scrutiny, transparency and the same for the European Parliament, this is all-important for us. On the budget for the next seven years, we need to get this right, because this is the budget of the European Union, also for the time after corona. it is here to stay, it needs to be ambitious and it needs to be enough to fulfil the promises which we have made to the people of Europe. We saw in the Council, 27 presidents and prime ministers fight for 27 national perspectives. Now the European Parliament will fight for the European perspective. We have listened to the Council, now is the time for the Council to listen to the European Parliament. What are our demands? What do we want? We want more young people to be able to travel and study in other countries to better know the European Union and the European way of living in different countries here in unity in the Union. For this, we need a bigger budget for Erasmus scholarships. We want us to be able to build more hospitals, to modernise existing hospitals. For this, we need an ambitious EU Health Programme, and we want Europe to be more innovative, to research more. For this, we need to prioritise the Horizon Europe programme. We want no one to be left behind in the transition to a green economy. The Just Transition Fund needs to be enforced. These are our expectations, these are our demands in order for us to be able to support the budget of the European Union for the next seven years. President von der Leyen, you said the budget is a ‘bitter pill that needs to be swallowed’. We do not want to swallow it in this form, we want to negotiate, we want to improve it, we want to start negotiations fast, we want to conclude negotiations fast and to have a vote fast because, President von der Leyen, you were a minister, President Michel, you were a prime minister, you know the Parliament always has the final say on the budget. This is why I say: let’s start the final negotiations fast and give a message to the people of Europe that we have an ambitious budget for the next seven years.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, at last! Finally, the European Council has also struck a blow. Today we can talk about a European response to the economic and social crisis caused by the coronavirus, today we can talk for the first time about common European debt to cope with the restart of our economies. The agreement on Next Generation EU changes the face of Europe: the Europe of solidarity has won, it has lost those who, for years, have told us that Europe no longer needed it, that it could be done without it, that all in all it was better closed within its borders to defend its national interests, as if these were something else than European interests. , almost opposed. Then came the coronavirus, with all the burden of suffering and pain for the people who did not make it, but also for those who every day fight for a job that is no longer there and that perhaps will not even return soon. We have discovered that we are all more fragile on our own, but we have also learned that crises do not result in the defence of small homelands, but in the relaunch of a genuine common European project. That is why today, Mr Michel, we must make a further effort, all together. If the Recovery Fund is a step forward, the multiannual financial framework is not good, it is not adequate, it needs to be improved and we are here for it. We certainly need extraordinary resources to get our economies off the market, which must be in everyone's interest, to those who are committed to showing clear signs of reviving and modernising their economies, and Parliament too will have to be able to have its say, but we also need to ensure the continuity of the Union's programmes and to give solidity to the new priorities for the future that we have all set ourselves here. , starting with the Green Deal. If we really want to address the next generation of Europeans, so much so that we have called the Next Generation EU plan, we cannot accept that programmes with a high European added value, such as Horizon for research, the Just transition fund for the green transition, InvestEU for the competitiveness of our businesses, Eu4Health for health or Erasmus, should be cut so heavily. Nor can we accept that Europe's resources should go to those who do not respect its values: we cannot use everyone's money to undermine the rule of law and democracy. We've taken important steps up here, it's only a last mile away. The citizens of Europe are returning to look to Europe with hope and confidence. Let us not waste this opportunity!

name: Luis Garicano (Renew).
text: – Mr President, we have succeeded. Many in this House and many in the Commission, Mrs Von der Leyen, and in the Council, Mr Michel, we have worked tirelessly to achieve an ambitious recovery fund that would enable Europe to tackle the exit from this crisis in a united way.  The European Parliament showed the way with two resolutions, in April and May, which showed that a pact was possible if we all thought of them as Europeans.  Europe has done its job, and now countries, all countries, must do their own.  Some are already celebrating it as if they have won the World Cup, but the reality is that all the work remains to be done.  The governments that are going to receive these funds have not yet done anything to solve the problems that these funds will be able to solve. We are only at the beginning of a long journey that we have to take to create the changes and transformations that our countries need.  Nothing is free; nor will those debt-financed EUR 750 billion fall on the shoulders of future generations. Our responsibility to those future generations is to use this money to build a better society. That's why, and just for that, we have to use these resources.  We must repeat this message in every corner: every corner of Europe, every corner of our countries. We have to explain that the reforms that have been so postponed and the investments that are necessary must be made now. We must use this opportunity to move towards a more humane Europe, in which all citizens have the capacities to enjoy true freedom that respects the environment, bets on knowledge technology and puts technology at the service of people.  How we invest this money will depend on Europe creating a strengthened or weakened crisis. It is time for rigor, commitment and responsibility.  From the European Parliament, we need to do everything necessary to ensure that this important investment that Europe is making is being spent well.

name: Marco Campomenosi (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank President Michel and President von der Leyen for being here today. This debate is very important but without a premise it risks losing its meaning: in these twenty years the European institutions have introduced a complex system of rules, incomprehensible to our citizens, a system of rules that has contributed so that Europe was, even before the COVID emergency, especially at that time, the area of the world that grew less than all of them. Not having a moment of self-criticism on this is, in my view, a serious problem. Then it is clear that, as many have said, the agreement reached at the European Council is macroeconomically relevant, as we all know. Even the supposed benefits for my country are still not entirely determinable: we do not yet know with what resources we will finance these interventions and some of the hypotheses concern us, because they risk penalising certain production sectors that are still important and that need support instead. On the contrary, we already know what recommendations the European Commission will make to my country: it will call for cuts in pensions, health and social services. I would not like us to be here in a few years' time commenting that with pension cuts in Italy we have financed the production of electric scooters in China. I would not like this veil of hypocrisy, which has reached this point since Maastricht to Lisbon, not finally to be lifted, because the risk is to give the citizens the impression that the crisis and its seriousness have not been understood and that solutions such as these are just a panacea unnecessary to solve the problems.

name: Rasmus Andresen (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her For the first time in the history of the European Union, we are responding to an economic crisis with common European bonds and investments. We Greens welcome this fundamental change in the system. It is economically wise and politically the right insight. If we want to emerge stronger from economic crises, we need a European Economic and Monetary Union. But the price of this step was high – we would say too high. You, Mr Michel, have sacrificed the EU budget to approve the reconstruction package. Instead of being European together, the EUR 1.8 trillion is spent primarily nationally. After a few stronger years, we will wake up to 2024 with an extremely low EU budget. Their only goal was to buy the consent of the stingy five through large discounts. Research, digitisation, nature conservation, people in coal regions, but also young people who want to travel through Europe through Erasmus programmes are the victims of this budget decision. They are paying the bill for unfair rebates to arrogant heads of government. Please explain to us why, in response to the biggest and global pandemic, you are cutting down the health programme, the proposed health programme! That makes no sense! The 30 percent climate investment is a step in the right direction. The climate movement, but also many here in Parliament, have fought for a very long time for more climate investment. But that is not enough to comply with the Paris climate agreement. We need more investment in climate protection and, above all, in biodiversity. We must ensure that not a single EU project in the budget is not compatible with the Paris climate agreement. Dirty fossil energy must no longer be promoted. Mr Michel, we Greens are ashamed that, on the subject of the rule of law, the paragraph you negotiated there has become the bargaining chip for the approval of Heads of State or Government such as Viktor Orban. Our rule of law and democracy should actually be a matter of course, because the EU is not an ATM. Your proposal makes it clearly too easy for Viktor Orban and others to block these measures in the future, and that is why you have to expect the strong opposition of the European Parliament in the coming weeks. The European Parliament does not sit in the public gallery. We are budgetary legislators and we take this role very seriously. We will negotiate constructively. We want an agreement, but we will also negotiate hard. Because a budget of this magnitude and on the terms is not acceptable to us.

name: Johan Van Overtveldt (ECR).
text: Mr President, the European Council has reached an agreement. This was also very necessary, because the European institutions could not and cannot afford to slip into an impasse at a time when the COVID pandemic is still building and is resulting in severe socio-economic consequences.  The recovery fund in front provides the necessary levers to allow our economies to recover quickly, but there are some loose ends to them. I'll pick two. The first is conditionality, where the agreement provides for an emergency break. It is rather unclear, I think, how that should work, whether that will work at all and what happens in the event of a deadlock at that level. The second point of ambiguity is certainly also the repayment, where I see certain principles, certain outlines of how this should be done, but whose concrete effect on how we are going to do so – and it is eur 750 billion – is not yet certain and is guaranteed to produce a number of discussions in the near and slightly further future.  I also continue to question the criteria used, in particular historical unemployment, where I seem to recognise a lot of reverse arithmetic. Finally, I deeply regret that the agreement reached by the Council is cutting the multiannual budget in terms of innovative and research programmes. Those are just the things we need to make our economy stronger and more resilient.

name: José Gusmão (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the issue of joint European debt is an important precedent, but it is debt that we are talking about. Until we have our own resources – and they have not advanced a millimetre at this Council meeting – what we are doing is advancing money from future budgets, and therefore it is only debt that we are talking about and it is appropriate not to mislead the citizens in that regard. And with this debt returns the famous macroeconomic conditionality, which led the European Union to a disastrous response to the previous crisis, disastrous for the economy and disastrous for citizens and the European project. And the price of achieving this solution was a smaller budget, a budget that will make the European Union a more unequal – and therefore less union – Union, and it was still necessary to buy the four countries that call themselves "frugais". Countries that talk to the rest of Europe about the rules but do not mind receiving cheques, which are now increased, outside european budget contribution rules. Countries that like to give moral lessons to the rest of the European Union but have accepted this bribe to agree to the plan that has been approved. Countries that talk about rules and talk about morale, but are the biggest beneficiaries of the existence of the single market and the rules of the single market, and even violate the rules on macroeconomic imbalances year after year, at least in the case of the Netherlands and Germany. And so we endorse this resolution, because this resolution says very clearly that the European Parliament will not accept the budget as it stands, and this implies talking about a more unequal Union and implies talking about this scandal which are the rebates, the cheques passed to some of europe's richest economies, and we will see if, in future debates, all the political groups of this House will remain faithful to the content of this resolution and the content of this refusal of the way of a Union more unequal, of a more unfair Union.

name: Carles Puigdemont i Casamajó (NI).
text: – Madam President, the news of the agreement this week has been very positive and full of hope at a moment of doubt and serious problems: a big step forward. This is what one would expect from the EU. Now it will be the Member States who must distribute resources with efficiency, with a federal mentality, and, above all, with great responsibility. This money comes from the effort of millions, and has been mobilised thanks to a marvellous word which is, or should be, the essence of the EU: solidarity. No one should ever forget this. A powerful economic recovery machine has been built, but the opportunity has been lost for this colossal energy to serve to strengthen democracy and the rule of law, especially in these times when dramatic situations, such as those of the Uyghur people, demand from Europe an indestructible moral authority in the human rights field.  There are states that will receive a lot of money but will not feel any obligation to change their treatment of or their opposition to national minorities, as we Catalans know well. Spain continues to spend millions on Pegasus software licences to spy on pro—independence leaders. Will Spain reject the recommendation of the United Nations Human Rights Committee? Can there be economic recovery without a democratic dimension? Yes, in China, but in Europe the slightest possibility that this might be possible is a nightmare that we should know how to shake off.

name: Esther de Lange (PPE).
text: Mr President, after the four days and nights described by President Michel, I have described this agreement as The good, the bad, and the ugly.  The good is the fact that there is an agreement. Not only about a multi-annual budget – which is always difficult, and we in Parliament still have consideration – but also about the recovery package in response to the corona crisis and its economic consequences. Because let's face it, it's not over yet. I would therefore like to use this place to appeal to the people outside – especially those who think that because the sun is shining there are no problems –: stick to the rules. It's not over yet. If nurses risk their own lives every day to save you, the least you can do is stick to the rules about corona.  Then, the bad: shortening on research and innovation, exactly what we need to get out of the economic crisis. But also on migration and border security. That is a good example, President Michel, of how your Council is spinning in circles on a permanent day. In the previous migration crisis, the countries were saying that we must solve this above all in Europe! And when the Commission and Parliament said, we are going to guard the borders together, it was said, okay, we are going to provide a budget for that. It is precisely that budget that has now been cut. I am sure, President Michel, that in the next migration crisis, your members will be shouting again: this is what we must do, above all, european!  Then, the ugly: as far as I'm concerned, the rule of law. I have seen the wording in every version of the Council conclusions become increasingly weak. But all is not lost, so I am very keen to take the outstretched hand of Commission President Von der Leyen to work on the basis of the 2018 Commission proposal to develop this regime. If I listen to how widely this is shared in the European Parliament, I think that today we are sending a very clear signal to the government in Poland, the government in the Czech Republic, also the government in Hungary, to all 27 Member States: that this Parliament will not give up the rule of law and respect for it. Because why is this so important? We are adding a new element to our European home with the recovery package, but respect for the rule of law is the foundation of everything we do. That is why we will have to work beyond just the meagre text of the Council, and I am very happy to accept that outstretched hand.

name: Margarida Marques (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Mr Presidents, this time there is a European response to the crisis. Citizens, families, businesses, civil society organisations, states can count on the European response. That's what we expected.  The European Parliament has set out the creation of a recovery fund based on the issuance of joint debt. The European response is based on this fund. I congratulate the European Commission on creatively and a ambitious and balanced European MFF proposal and Recovery Plan combined with each other has been creative and built. Member States are certainly satisfied with the financial envelopes at their disposal. But we have a concern which, as President Von der Leyen said, is shared by the European Commission: how to relaunch strategic programmes for the future and increase our resilience, such as Erasmus, Horizon Europe, Digital Europe, EU4Health, Creative Europe or Rights and Values? That is why the European Parliament is strongly welcomed by the European response, but it will not stop using all the mechanisms at its disposal to obtain a more robust European Union budget. And for that we count on the Commission, the institution that watches over the interest of the Union. Yes, it is in the Union's interest that is at stake, it is European added value, but we also have european leaders who, in this long negotiation, have defended the European interest beyond their national interests. And we want a mid-term review that also analyzes gender mainstreaming and sees where we are in the climate goals. But above all, it discusses the financing of the European Union budget. Until then we have to introduce new own resources, such as the digital tax or a tax on financial transactions. Relying on the Union budget mostly on the percentage of the Gross National Income of the Member States leads to the same disputes every 7 years. Finally, the Conference on the Future of Europe must play an important role here.

name: Valérie Hayer (Renew).
text: Madam President, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this pandemic has stunned us. It stunned europeans in the face of our impotence in the first few weeks. While our economies, our workers, are being hit hard, our responsibility as elected officials is to restore hope. The hope that we will be better prepared in the future to deal with any health crisis, however sudden it may be. The hope that our world of tomorrow will be more resilient, greener, more innovative, more united.  It is in this spirit that the Heads of State and Government have adopted this stimulus package. This is an absolutely major step forward for our future, a historic moment. I believe that no one in this Chamber will be able to challenge it unless we show absolute bad faith. So I extend to you, Mr President, my sincere congratulations for reaching agreement on this extraordinary budget. We strongly support him. Yet the task has not been easy, far from it. But honestly, what could be more predictable? Heads of state and government are entangled in unanimity; they drag their own budgetary constraints to Brussels and know full well that they will be judged according to an absolutely intransigent national reading grid. This has to stop! Madam President, Mr President, in the position we are going to adopt today, we MEPs are calling for a clear and binding commitment to the rapid introduction of new own resources. No fuzzy terms, such as 'in sight' or 'possibly'. We ask GAFA, multinationals that practice tax optimization, major Chinese polluting industries to contribute. They are the ones who have to bear the burden of this loan. In fact, this is the raison d'être, the very essence of this recovery plan: to ensure solidarity between our countries, without increasing the burden on our citizens. Clearly, we want to enshrine in law what has been done in the spirit. Our request is part of the dynamics of your agreement. Mr President, we can now start negotiating this regular budget together, with confidence, ambition and speed.

name: Jaak Madison (ID).
text: – For a start, I am very pleased to hear the praises of all the people and the great congratulations on the agreement reached. My problem is rather that we are still relying on the so-to-speak underlying cause. Why is EUR 750 billion borrowed on behalf of the European Union, and what is the real reason for this? The real reason, officially, according to the European Commission, is that many Member States do not receive such a favourable loan. But why can't they? Because their own national borrowing burden is too high. But why is it too big? Because the economy is not working, but why the economy is not functioning is that they will not be able to run their economy if the regulations of the European Union, the directives, the laws have combed them so much, because they will inevitably not work in uniform regulations across the European Union. Therefore, now those countries that have been economical, frugal, conservative in financial policy, like Estonia, my own country, which is perhaps the least indebted in the world to date, must accept a huge loan because many European countries have simply lived above their capabilities for decades. Not to mention, of course, the political problem that, when we talk about the rule of law, we are talking about Poland, Hungary – all of this, very sweet, but with the rule of law, there is no way to do that that we go around the corner from the Treaties, because the Treaties would not allow the European Commission to set a precedent for a giant loan where we do not even know how we will pay it back, let alone new taxes. I am therefore quite sure that it will go to a very large number of higher courts across the European Union, as was the case in Germany and will certainly happen in Estonia. Thank you and hope for the best for the future of Europe, which is not just the European Union.

name: Bas Eickhout (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to use my minute to really address the ‘Frugals’, the five Frugals in your Council where all our political families have our issues, and I think we have to be fair on that.  But the questions to the Frugals would be, what were you thinking? Ten years after a euro crisis when there is finally a momentum for a public investment plan – let’s cut it. A health crisis hitting Europe everywhere – let’s cut the EU for Health Programme.  A seven-year EU budget investing in our next decade – let’s cut the budget for research. The next big crisis being climate change – let’s cut the Just Transition Fund. The European values being challenged everywhere – let’s kick the rule of law can down the road, again.  Yes dear Frugals, you have your rebates, but we are discussing the future of Europe here and that is in everyone’s interest, certainly in yours. We as a European Parliament are offering you this summer to rethink your priorities.

name: Bogdan Rzońca (ECR).
text: – I would like to say that we simply need the Multiannual Financial Framework and the Reconstruction Instrument. No matter what we are talking about here today, however, I would like to believe that what the Council has prepared after long and painous negotiations, including with the important participation of Polish, deserves recognition. And I would like to stress strongly that I see that, however, the idea of solidarity and responsibility has taken a mountain over the national selfishness that we were afraid of.  I firmly believe that no one will be harmed by what has been prepared during these four days. I believe this strongly, even though the rule of law is very visible here. Poland and Hungary, and all countries, are in favour of the rule of law as for clean air as for clean water, as for a good climate. And I hope that there will not be a situation where, on false grounds – for example, that a judge is unwell – one of the nations or one of the states is punished. I believe in the integrity of the Council, the Union, the government and Mrs von der Leyen in this matter. If there is a review of the law in the countries of the European Union, it will be a fair review. We are not afraid of the rule of law, but we are afraid of false, bad judges. We also hope that very soon this money will be released, released to the market, that it will be dedicated to poorer regions, to entrepreneurs, to those who need protection at work. I firmly believe that we will go with these new financial instruments – with the various shortcomings that others have talked about here – without a reverse run. I therefore wish you good luck and good use of these funds in all countries.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, I hear that the agreement reached in the European Council is historic.
