But we know, from experience and lucidity, that the doors sometimes open close very quickly before the logics of competition and competition. The future will tell. But historicity cannot be short-term, and the agreement reached in the Council came at the cost of cuts in the long-term policies of the European Union: CAP, research, Erasmus, health, green pact and ESF. The agreement was also reached with a worrying start to the renationalisation of European policies. I believe that, in the end, this agreement marks that national interests have prevailed over the European policies we defend. In conclusion, I want to say to the Council that the European Parliament has the final say, that we are co-decision-makers on regulations and that we are the guarantors of the Community method.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Europe of solidarity was born on 21 July. This date will certainly be remembered as the beginning of a new era: with EUR 750 billion earmarked to combat the economic crisis and with the issue of common securities we have planted the seed of the Europe of the future. We will soon reap the benefits and be generous, we will also distribute them to those who hoped to collect only rubble, such as Italian and foreign sovereignists. Of course, there is still much to be done. The European Parliament will speak out to improve the agreement: some of the cuts, wanted by countries that call themselves 'frugal', are soothing and nonsensical. How can the Eu ropean Union's health programme be cut in the midst of a health emergency? We must also defend investment in the south of Europe and relaunch tourism and the cultural industry, which have suffered more than others from the pandemic crisis. We are certainly proud of the work that has been done, the path taken is the right one. The dream of Spinelli and the other founding fathers returns to save this Europe, which died yesterday. We are not afraid to move forward: the future awaits us.

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Congratulations to the European Council for this rapid agreement. That is a strong signal. It is a signal that Europe is arguing, that Europe is fighting for different interests, but that the Member States are ultimately able to quickly find common positions. This is also the important message to the citizens: Europe is reliable, we stand in solidarity and we face up to the challenges together. That is why this paper is a good basis for negotiation. But we do not want and we cannot simply nod off this package. The money will not flow until 1 January. So we still have a few weeks to agree on one or the other improvement. However, we also have issues that we need to discuss, namely: have we really done enough to ensure that the money is also channelled into sensible investments and that we do not simply keep old structures alive with fresh money? Why did the Member States not have the courage to really enable the European Union to do European programming, as we are really doing successfully in many regional and structural funds? Why have the Member States insisted that they present programmes on their own responsibility and that we do not stand together as the European Union? My second question to you, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, is this: how do we ensure that not only the one per cent of European money as a share of European GDP – or now, for the next two or three years, we will get to 3 or 4%, but above all the 49% of European GDP that is in the Member States – in the cities and municipalities, in the regions? , in the nation states – are they really well positioned? After all, our entire european Union package can only be effective if the Member States, with their 49% in the coming weeks and months, take the right measures. And this message should also come from us in the European Parliament, that we have a clear expectation here also of the governments and parliaments in the Member States.

name: Tiemo Wölken (S&D).
text: Madam President, Mrs von der Leyen, Mr Michel, I would like to thank mrs von der Leyen for the work he has It is good that you have come out of the negotiations with a result, but it is not good what is in this compromise. We will not swallow the bitter pill that you mentioned here today that we have been served. Your proposal cuts funding where it is particularly important for the future viability of the European Union. The InvestEU programme, which supports investment in climate neutrality, will be cut from EUR 31.6 billion to EUR 8.4 billion. For socially just change, we have the Just Transition Fund, cut from 40 billion to 17.5 billion. In the midst of a global pandemic, you are cutting health policy to just EUR 240 million per year. How can that be? The reconstruction programme is called Next Generation EU. At the moment, it looks as if Next Generation EU means that the climate crisis, digitalisation, health should be the next generation, not us. This is unacceptable. And in order to prevent these citizens' priorities from being disregarded in this way, it must be clear that we, as the European Parliament, need a say in the reconstruction programme. Then there is the biggest weakness: the rule of law. The draft is totally unacceptable at this point. The rule of law is the common principle, is the basis of cooperation, the basis for trust and a protective umbrella for our fundamental rights. It is precisely this agreement that makes the pill so bitter. Parliament will fight for a better prescription for the pill of the budget until there is so much rule of law in it that journalists, judges, demonstrators and citizens can sleep calmly again, because their fundamental rights are protected.

name: Moritz Körner (Renew).
text: Madam President, Mrs von der Leyen, Mr Michel, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. It is good that we have a result from this summit. But I believe that the weekend has also shown that the Member States see the European Union solely as an ATM. It's just a matter of paying as little as possible and getting as much out of it as possible. And, by the way, all the Member States. The thrifty are primarily concerned with paying as little as possible into it, the others are concerned with getting as much out of it as possible. Ladies and gentlemen, however, the European Union is not an ATM, it must become a future insurance policy. And that is precisely why we must set the tone for the future – with Erasmus, with education, with research and with real European projects, for example, with a real hydrogen union. The European Union must be strong where the Member States cannot be strong. However, some Member States actually see this EU as an ATM in the sense that they can enrich themselves and their friends from EU money. We must prevent this from happening. We need a bailout for the rule of law in Europe to ensure that the money no longer goes to would-be autocrats or their corrupt friends. We have to make sure of that. At this point, Merkel & Co. let themselves be dragged over the table at this Orban summit, and this European Parliament will not accept that.

name: Gunnar Beck (ID).
text: Madam President, good news first: Brexit has saved Britain EUR 80 billion net, roughly the sum the Recovery Fund would have cost Britain. Never let a good crisis go to waste! As a result, the EU is issuing €1.8 trillion by 2027 and is in debt of €750 billion. This is the coup d'Etat. Articles 310 and 311 TFEU state: "The EU budget must be balanced .... [and] will ... fully financed from own resources." Clear words, but the EU is making debts – illegal! Confucius said: "Where words lose their meaning, peoples lose their freedom" – not in Hungary or Poland, but through Brussels and Berlin. Merkel scoffs as if Germany is an omnipotence like the US after the war, and imposes German tax money on other germans, as it were. The Germans have the lowest private wealth in the euro zone, the highest taxes in the world, record electricity prices and the lowest home ownership rate. Rich Germany has very poor citizens. Von der Leyen plans EU taxes and illegally makes EU debts. Lagarde prints trillions of euros – illegal. Three women govern the EU – no problem. But it is the three most expensive women in Europe since Madame de Pompadour.

name: Petra De Sutter (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, President von der Leyen, President Michel, yes, the agreement is historic. Of course, we acknowledge that. But as a doctor, I must say I am disappointed, because of the cuts in the Health Programme. We are in the middle of the crisis. We are at the beginning of the second wave. We all see the figures rising again in Europe.  I cannot understand – I cannot explain to my colleagues – why the Member States did not understand this as an absolute priority. And we cannot compare the figures in the proposal now with previous figures because we did not have a COVID crisis then.  I’m also a researcher and a professor. I cannot explain to my students why Erasmus has received cuts. I cannot explain to my fellow researchers why Horizon Europe is not what it should be because we need that also for innovation, for start-ups, for SMEs, for our power, our leadership role in the world.  We’ve believed the ambition of the Commission in respect of the Green Deal and the Digital Transition, and these are the priorities that are aimed to the future, that we are missing in this proposal. So please, if we negotiate the MFF, listen to us and top up these essential programmes.  (Applause)

name: Derk Jan Eppink (ECR).
text: Mr President, the European summit ended with Mr Rutte's betrayal. After four days of shadow boxing, he threw in the towel and left.  What is the result? We are going to have a higher EU budget, despite the British. There will be European taxes, and also European debt – which Mr Rutte has always said he is against. He talks about an emergency braking procedure, but that is actually a farce – there is no plug that you can pull out – and thus leads the Netherlands into the transfer union.  France is suspending pension reform, Spain is introducing a basic income and Dutch pensions are being cut. That's very bitter for these people, and they don't understand that. That is why I am calling for a referendum in the Netherlands on this redistribution plan. Let the people decide for themselves their money.

name: Clare Daly (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, as you know, yesterday Dr Syed Ali, a frontline health-care worker, died in Dublin’s Mater Hospital, a day before his 60th birthday. He is one of the many casualties to this health crisis and I have to say, sitting here, I’m really struck by the shocking disconnect between the words spoken, the deal before us and the reality for his family and for the citizens of Europe. We have been through an unprecedented health crisis. We’re still in it. In May, the Commission told us it needed EUR 9.4 billion for a new stand-alone health programme, the first instalment of a necessary EUR 70 billion programme. Instead, we get nothing for health in the recovery and EUR 1.7 billion in the MFF, while EUR 13.5 billion goes on our defence budget. What an insult to Dr Ali. We talk about solidarity, but your conditions on your form sound very much like austerity to me, with no such conditions on the rule of law. I’m sorry, but it is a monument to European hypocrisy.

name: Clara Ponsatí Obiols (NI).
text: – Madam President, I welcome the agreement of the Council. European citizens need the Recovery Fund to get back on their feet and face the future with hope, but to boost back our economies, we need more than hard work and money. We need to boost all our creative potential and that means good government, rule of law, science and technology. That’s why it’s so disturbing that the Council has used science as the cash cow for the negotiations. COVID-19 makes the value of research more evident than ever, but 27 prime ministers failed to realise that, so I call on this Parliament to stand up for the science budget.  Council overruled the rule of law and science, but I am glad they agreed on a control mechanism so that recovery funds are used productively. Spain will be a major recipient and this money needs to be put to good use – and yes, this requires external control because Spain is the Member State where the royal house is the centre of a massive corruption scheme but the government and parliament refuse to investigate. Spain is the country that spends billions on submarines but cannot feed its dogs, or airports where planes never fly. Spain is the champion of high-speed trains, while commuter transit remains dangerously underinvested. Spain is the country that bails out the banks, not the people, and never ask banks for any money back. So I’m glad someone will be looking closely at how these funds are spent.

name: Andrzej Halicki (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. Congratulations, Mr President. Indeed, the European Union summit has been a success, because it is a historic moment when such great measures (potential measures – I hope that the ratification process of this plan will be just as effective) can revive, can save the European economy after this pandemic crisis. An important and very important element is also that European measures will be protected by the rule of law mechanism. This is undoubtedly a success, but we in Parliament here will soon be adopting a budget, a multiannual plan, to also pursue the objectives that we are talking about. How can we sign the cuts in the Just Transition Fund with one hand, which, after all, aims to build the practical objective of achieving climate neutrality in 2050 and say that this is our priority? These regions, coal regions such as Upper Silesia, need support. We must strengthen this fund, not limit it. We cannot tell the young citizens of our countries that a common Europe thinks about them, cares about their safety and education, and at the same time reduces the Erasmus+ programme by 50%, which is, after all, a banner for thinking about this common, modern, open Europe with development opportunities for young people as well. A committee to fight cancer will be working here in Parliament from September. This is the biggest killer in Europe today. After the pandemic, we have further health protection and safety challenges. We have practically erased health policy from the multiannual financial plan – or does this proposal erase it. We cannot agree to this here in Parliament.  We talk a lot about the rule of law. If the rule of law is so important to all of us, after all, the Rights and Values programme, which promotes common values, promotes democracy, should be strengthened – and its prestige, and its financial support. We have border protection. We have other tasks: learning, and so on. Europe must be stronger and more united. And I think we will achieve this together, thinking about these priorities also from a financial point of view. We need to improve this budget.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D).
text: – Madam President, President Von der Leyen, President Michel, the European Councils often generate a lot of anticipation and most of them a lot of disappointment and frustration. But this has not been the case and I want to congratulate you on that. You have done a fantastic job and have reached a historic agreement. They have had the courage, at last, to do what had to be done. The qualitative leap we make in European construction finally lives up to that Monnet phrase that Europe is built in crises.  The amount of the plan is less than we asked for, but it is still important, and I just hope it is sufficient. What is not enough is the financial framework and there they have made a mistake. It cannot be that, for the third time, we are re-adopting budgets lower than the previous septenio, because the needs are still increasing. And here I am not talking about the needs generated by the coronavirus crisis, because for that we already have the recovery plan. But before this virus we had many needs and also need to be funded. I am talking about continuing to investigate cancer or Alzheimer's, of continuing to support innovative industrial projects and more efficient modes of transport, of helping our staff with training, of helping our young people enter the labour market, of combating child poverty. That's still there and it also needs strong budgets. And it is a pity that this European spirit that perregulateed the summit could not keep its eyes up from that cold accounting.  But let's sit down, see how we make it better. In income and expenses, because both are important. Because I'm sure we can find an agreement and it will be a simply perfect agreement.

name: Guy Verhofstadt (Renew).
text: – (start of speech off mike) ... I have to tell you that we were with a few lone rangers that, since the outbreak of the financial crisis, started to say that eurobonds and new own resources were needed, and everybody said, ‘impossible, unrealistic, a dream that will never happen. This is Europe.’ Well, it is happening, and so I’m pleased with the outcome of this summit, and I think it’s historic. Yes, it’s historic. The first leap forward was the internal market; the second leap forward was the euro; the third leap forward is the fact that Europe will issue bonds for the first time and will increase its fiscal capacity in a dramatic way. So, I’m pleased and this is historic. But there are also weaknesses in this plan, let’s be honest. And the most important weakness is due to what? Yes, the rule of unanimity. And that’s the reason why the pan—European projects have been gutted and that the direct transfers to the Member States and the rebates for the frugals are still there. I think that – I will be very blunt here, in this House, and I think that I’m speaking for the whole House –this House will not give its green light for this package and for the MFF if this is not rectified, if we again do not have these pan-European projects as the priority in the MFF – and it’s easy to do! The easy way to do it is to start with its own resources earlier than foreseen in the plan. In the plan, it’s foreseen for 2023. My proposal is to start in 2021. And finally, my last point, Madam President, before you use your weapon again against me – like every time. There needs to be a co-decision by Parliament. We’re going to spend and collect EUR 750 billion. That is only possible with democratic control. We are in Europe. We are not in China or in Russia. (Applause)

name: President. –
text: It was a good job, Mr Verhofstadt, that I didn’t cut you off! The holidays are coming...

name: Georg Mayer (ID).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We live in special times. I think we all know that. Special times, of course, also need special measures. There is much at stake in this financial package. We are talking about a one with twelve digits behind it. There is a lot at stake, it is about very, very much. These packages and these decisions will affect generations after us, will influence fiscal policy for generations after us. Strangely enough, everyone seems to have come home as winners at this summit. Merkel, Kurz, Macron have come home and announced profitable negotiations, got something out of it for their states. However, once you have negotiated, common sense knows that this is simply not possible. It cannot leave every negotiation as a winner. Recently, there have been voices even saying that Germany and France will be the beneficiaries of these aid measures at the end of the day, because the criteria have been changed, because they have been based on size. And it is astonishing that everyone is leaving these negotiations as winners. Away from these sleight of hand – admittedly, they are very, very large pockets – what we did not want comes: the debt union comes. Whether this debt union is compatible with the EU Treaties is still to be verified; some colleagues have already hinted at it. The rule of law cannot only apply to others, but must also apply to ourselves. What was made clear at this summit, in any case, is that we are witnessing the formation of a bloc. We are experiencing a north-south and an east-west block. This can only be detrimental to an alleged solidarity union – which this Union is supposed to be. Ladies and gentlemen, solidarity can never be a one-way street.

name: Henrike Hahn (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It is good that we now have a negotiating position at this EU summit, and it is a strong sign that we in Europe are taking our hands and supporting each other. But the negotiations are only really beginning. It is unacceptable: cuts in future programmes, health and research, no strong hand in the violation of the rule of law and too little climate protection. We in this Parliament have promised to save the earth – with a climate-neutral Europe by 2050 at the latest, with a Green Deal as a stimulus programme. That means decarbonising the industry. To achieve this, we need strong research to support small and medium-sized enterprises. We cannot afford fossil fuels. Horizon Europe, InvestEU and Solvency Assistance Instrument are instruments for the future. We cannot accept such cuts. We have promised to stand by the people with a strong fund for a fair transition, and some regions have already been in the process of drafting their transitional plans. The European Council is now letting people down. That is not possible! We need a move towards a sustainable, solidarity-based economy with all the positive opportunities in it, and that is our responsibility.

name: Peter Lundgren (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Let me begin by stating that this package of measures is in direct conflict with Articles 310 and 311. It is clear from this: europe is not allowed to borrow money for its budget. There is also one thing that lies with us Members of the House. Ensure compliance with the rules and not only round them up and not care at all about a regulatory framework that we have jointly agreed on.  Then there is a lot of whining about stingy countries. We have a situation in Sweden where people die in waiting lists and operating queues. At the same time, we have a Prime Minister who agrees to send only additional money abroad. They say we've got discounts. In fact, we have received an extended expenditure of six billion more in membership fees. How to stand and call it a discount, it goes my mind. Now you are giving europe the right to tax too, and they are being given their own resources. But Stefan Löfven, I want to tell you: I hope that the voters' verdict in 2022 will be tough on you and your party, because you sold out Sweden. You sold out the Swedes.

name: Marc Botenga (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, for the first time, the European Union is going to lend common money and then put it in a pot and make it available through transfers to countries that need it. That is a step in the right direction, let us say. Especially to the Mark Ruttes of this world, who, even in this pandemic, did not want to show a shred of solidarity. To all those people who, when they see that the retirement age is lower elsewhere, do not think: perhaps our workers can also retire earlier, but impose anti-social dictates on other countries.  Mais je vais aussi vous mettre en garde parce que vous avez encapsulé cet avatar de solidarité européenne dans le Semestre européen. Pour rappel, ce Semestre européen a permis à la Commission de conseiller 63 fois aux États membres de couper dans leurs soins de santé. Alors, si aujourd'hui vous allez utiliser ce plan pour imposer des réformes asociales, cela ne passera pas. Si vous vous permettez de faire payer cette crise aux travailleurs, vous nous trouverez sur votre chemin.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the gruelling marathon of the European Council has given birth to an historic agreement, which strongly overcomes the stumbling block of tomorrow, but the horizon of the future is still uncertain and far away. It was imperative to decide and it was decided. We saved the amount of NextGenEU, 750 billion to overcome the mistakes of austerity, and as an Italian I thank Prime Minister Conte with real heart for having fought with tenacity and courage against the downward haggling of the "frugal". But as a European I tell you that if it had been our Parliament that decided, and not an anachronistic intergovernmental body hostage to electoral blackmail, today we would have much more than 750 billion. Tomorrow's Europe programmes – Horizon Europe, EU4Health, Erasmus+ – would not have been mutilated; we would have web, carbon and Tobin tax as early as 2021, and the leaders of the richest 10 % of European citizens could never have overrun the remaining 90 %, plumping up the odious privilege of rebates. As a Parliament we are ready to fight, you can bet! That is why the conference on the future of Europe must lead to a revision of the Treaties: with the Council unanimously, everyone can win, but europe can never really win.

name: József Szájer (PPE).
text: "There is a lot of talk in this house about the rule of law by people who have no idea what that means. For me, the rule of law means freedom, national independence and democracy. The rule of law means the rule of law instead of the rule of the people. For 30 years, my generation has fought to make this not only the inherited privilege of those living in the western part of Europe. We have fought for this, but I will also tell you what the rule of law does not mean, for which many people here want to use it. It does not report unrefined, unwritten rules. It doesn't mean double standards. It's when someone gets punished for the same reason someone else is praised. It does not mean sanctioning or shutting down political ideologies that some people do not like. But that's what some people here use the slogan of the rule of law for. It is emptied and subordinated to party political objectives. Those who talk about the rule of law should not roll out voting rules just so that the result they like comes out, as they did recently when the Sargentini report was voted on. If you are a believer in the rule of law, do not be alarmed by dissenting opinions, give the accused the floor to defend himself. Recently, in the debate on Hungary, you refused to let the Hungarian Minister give his position. One of the oldest principles of the rule of law comes from Roman law: "nullum crimen sine lege", no punishment, no law. In this House, however, solutions are being pushed where it would be determined not on the basis of normative, non-legal criteria that the rule of law would be violated, but would already impose serious financial penalties in the event of suspicion and would not guarantee equal treatment. That's the communist model. It's the Orwellian model of thought police that wants to punish intent. It's the Soviet way of screwing up the law to educate and blackmail political dissidents. We've seen this before. We've been victims of similar endeavors. We beat them, and we're not going to let them come back through the back door. Europe deserves a better, very better rule of law. And Madam President, if you would allow me a point of order: in this House some Members like to lecture certain countries to certain politicians about observing rules in the name of the rule of law. However, this Parliament is in breach itself in this moment, of its own Rules of Procedure – Rules 182 and 187 – which clearly say that voting can start only after the debate on the floor is finished. We are debating still, but the voting has already started. This is a violation of our own values. So, let's sweep in front of our own house first before we condemn others.

name: President. –
text: Just for the record, Mr Szájer, the final vote takes place after the debate. I move now to the next speaker, Mr Fernández, for one and a half minutes.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D).
text: – Madam President, first of all, we must recognise that the agreement of the Last Days European Council represents a momentous historic step in the process of European construction.  An agreement which continues Parliament's request in our May resolution, in which we called for the creation of a financing instrument through Community debt to be repayed with more own resources to help the European economy in the face of this crisis.  An important, key, fundamental agreement in which some government, such as Spanish, led by Pedro Sánchez, has played an essential role.  But in this agreement there are also some issues that we have to question. And the first is the regular budget, as some items do not grow what they should. And I will make special reference to the Fair Transition Fund, because those regions ⸺ like mine, Asturias⸺ which face a momentous challenge also, namely to modernize their economy, need stronger European support.  On the other hand, for the Recovery and Resilience Mechanism ⸺instrument to assist countries in investment and reforms⸺ governance is envisaged in the European Council agreement which this Parliament cannot approve.  We need governance with clear democratic legitimacy; we need governance in which citizens see their interests represented. And this Parliament will have its word and we will meet with the Council in the tripartite negotiations before the end of the year.

name: Stéphane Séjourné (Renew).
text: Madam President, Mr President, this agreement is historic, as everyone has said - not to the displeasure of the far right of this Chamber - since the beginning of this session. It may not be your story, Mr. Bay, but it is ours. This agreement reflects the extraordinary impetus that has enabled the creation of a major stimulus fund in addition to the European budget. We must also, ladies and gentlemen, be aware of where we are coming from: a few weeks ago, we were told this impossible agreement. Some had vetoed the very principle of an extraordinary stimulus package, with a veto on transfers, a veto on the principle of common debt, and this was achieved. This is a great step forward for Europe and I think we must all salute it. Now this resolution has the delicate task of welcoming this historic agreement while recalling the demands of the representatives of the European people that we are as Members. I would have liked, perhaps, to be more positive about the agreement, but at the same time we are the 28th voice in this negotiation and we are proposing legitimate and concrete changes for the lives of European citizens: more funds for Erasmus, more health, and above all more effective own resources more quickly. I agree with mr Guy Verhofstadt's proposal for a faster repayment of our common debt. Madam President, we have heard that four days of discussions between heads of state and government is the price of democracy. I agree, nowhere on another continent can 27 Member States agree in four days, with such an ambitious plan. However, bear in mind that a few weeks of negotiations with the European Parliament on a budget that commits us for 7 years is also the price of democracy: we will be ambitious, we will not block but we will be at the rendezvous of history.

name: Tom Vandendriessche (ID).
text: – Mr President, EUR 13 billion: that is how much Belgium should contribute net to the European Union's corona recovery fund. In addition, our contribution to the European budget is increasing by more than EUR 1 billion a year. However, Belgium is already facing a budget deficit of EUR 50 billion and 120 % of public debt as a matter of 120% of the debt caused by this corona crisis.  Who gets this explained to their constituents? Who will get it explained to my citizens that there is no money for humane pensions, that there is no money for care, that there is no money for tens of thousands of families who are on the brink of collapse, but that billions are waiting for the European Union's Policy of St Nicholas? I can't get that explained.  Or maybe it is. The more money the Eurocrats get, the more power they gain over states and thus, the more control they gain over citizens. Creating dependency without people ever choosing to. Because for 15 years, these Eurofanatics have lost every referendum. Years of sabotage and blackmail over Brexit did not work. In order to prevent more countries from playing their democracy and opting for their freedom, they now want to introduce European debt and European taxes. In this way they want to build a financial and fiscal prison from which one can no longer escape. This European Union is becoming something we have never chosen.

name: Tilly Metz (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Madam President of the Commission, Mr President, I would like to thank the President-in-The-European President for the work he has There is a clear majority in this House in favour of more solidarity, more transparency, more sustainability, more Europe. It is not a question of which country gets what or how much, no, my question is: what do we invest in? Saving the economy must not come at the expense of forward-looking programmes. How, for example, can we talk about Next Generation and cut spending on education? How can you want to implement a Green Deal and halve the budget for the Just Transition Fund? In the midst of a pandemic, how can governments cancel planned spending on health and research? And what about our hopes for a more sustainable common agricultural policy if the planned rural development subsidy is halved? These cuts cannot be borne by this Parliament. Because we are not rebuilding after reconstruction, but during reconstruction.

name: Carlo Fidanza (ECR).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, out of the rhetoric and triumphalism, it took only a few hours to discover that the agreement of 21 July is not the best possible agreement. In this resolution, they are the same ones who welcome their prime ministers in the national parliaments with standing ovations, as happened to Conte yesterday in the Italian Parliament. Of course, there is money on paper, but we were right when we said that the answer is late and insufficient, when we said that it is wrong to go ahead with discounts on national contributions, that the part of the subsidies has been too small, that the money will come too late, when too many businesses will already be closed down and that is why we needed a bridge mechanism to help them immediately. We were right to denounce a governance full of conditionality, which risks commissionering our economic choices, and we were right, again, to say that, instead of asking for contributions from the Chinese, the giants of the web or finance, postponed to a date to be allocated, from 1 January 2021 you will massacre European companies with the plastic tax. We were right and you wrote it.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like my first words to be of support and affection to the families of the deceased, who will always be in our memory, while I wish to pay tribute to all the workers who have been and continue to be fighting the pandemic.  The deal is positive. It's a step forward and you don't have to waste time, not a minute, because time is pressing and we're late. It is necessary to act quickly and courageously. It is a plan of European solidarity, but also of cohesion. It is a historic agreement because never had all Member States generated joint debt. Because of its magnitude and also because it is an important step in the process of European integration.  The aim is very clear: to recover employment, to recover European recovery, to protect Europe and to safeguard lives. The leadership of Chancellor Merkel and the Commission's own president, Ursula von der Leyen, both popular women, is indisputable here. This plan requires responsibility, stability and, at the same time, an ambitious and robust programme of reforms. I am referring to all Member States. In the past Spain did so with the Government of Rajoy and gave good results. Europe has complied. It is now up to the Member States to comply with citizens, especially in Spain, where the general interest has to prevail over balances of power. I have to tell you that you have to control that money very well so that it is spent where it is needed most.  The second part of the agreement, the Multiannual Financial Framework, is not satisfactory. We disagree with the unjustified and unjustifiable cuts. Specifically, 10% cut in the common agricultural policy and the field is absolutely unjustified. The field cannot be payment to this negotiation, especially when the field has been exemplary in its conduct during the pandemic. Also cuts in health, cuts in the right transition, cuts in education, in Erasmus. All these cuts put Europe's future at stake.  And finally, to tell you that I am very concerned about the protection of the rule of law. We need mechanisms to ensure a defence of the rule of law. Without a rule of law there is no democracy, but without democracy there is no Europe.

name: Kati Piri (S&D).
text: – Madam President, let me start off positively. So let me first congratulate President Michel and President von der Leyen on what has been achieved on the Recovery Fund. I think a large majority in this Parliament agrees that it was innovative, it is what the people need right now, those people who are afraid of losing their jobs. So congratulations, for that is forward-looking.  This is where the praise stops though, because I do believe that with the MFF it’s not a budget that is a budget for the challenges we are facing as Europe right now. It’s a budget which lacks ambition, it lacks modernity, and President von der Leyen, you can’t be satisfied with this as the European Commission. Let me just give you one example. When this crisis is leading to a global inequality, what do we do? We cut the money for development aid.  The most important point: because of money we can negotiate, but we can’t negotiate on our values, and the fact in itself that we have law professors, we have EU leaders, we have journalists who are all having a different interpretation about what the European Council has agreed on when it comes to the rule of law, is a bad signal. I hear some people saying it’s very good that for the first time we mention the rule of law and the budget together. This is not something to be proud of: this we didn’t need 15 years ago. Now we have two countries in the European Union who, according to Freedom House, are a hybrid regime and no longer in the group of democracies.  So please, for my party, for my group – and I hope for a majority in this Parliament – we have to have clear wording on rule of law before we can agree to this budget. It’s not about money: it’s about principles.

name: Katalin Cseh (Renew).
text: – Madam President, the editor-in-chief of Hungary’s largest independent news portal, Index, was fired yesterday, a few hours after Mr Orbán proclaimed his victory over Brussels. I say to President von der Leyen and President Michel: empty words without action only serve to embolden the populists. This budget is our historic chance to rebuild and renew Europe, and I’m very glad we have this deal. But make no mistake, this deal is what we make of it. It can strengthen Europe or it can help the anti-European populists. Because yet again the Council failed to deliver a strong rule of law mechanism – a clear link between EU values and EU money. And Parliament’s call should be clear: no more empty promises on values, no more uncontrolled flows of EU money to the pockets of corrupted oligarchs but direct funds to local communities who need them now more than ever before. We ask the Commission to take action and take leadership on these commitments, and we ask the German Presidency to live up to Chancellor Merkel’s promises and treat rule of law as a top priority. Anything less than concrete action is unacceptable for us. (Applause)

name: Hélène Laporte (ID).
text: Madam President, the four days and nights of bitter negotiations have not honoured the European Union, which is ending this summit divided as never before. Weary of war, an agreement was reached by unravelling the balances of the original project, symbolic of a historic failure on several levels. A failure for Europe, whose image is tarnished by irreversible antagonisms. A failure, then, regarding the credibility of the project. Emmanuel Macron said on Tuesday night that the French taxpayer would pay nothing for the stimulus package. But, objectively, who can believe this fable? We are really walking on water with the European Union. How can we repay a loan with own resources that do not currently exist and which will require a unanimous decision of the Member States, assuming that they are sufficient to allow repayment? This common borrowing is contrary to Article 311 of the TFUE, and we will pay for it until 2058. It constitutes unacceptable budgetary integration. I fear and condemn the next step, which is undoubtedly the creation of a European Treasury and its corollary, namely a generalised mutualisation of debts. There is also a failure in terms of priorities. How is the outright abolition of the EU4Health health programme explained when it was Europe's ad hoc response to the pandemic? Public health is a challenge that crosses borders, but clearly no lessons have been learned from this crisis. There is also a failure in terms of broken commitments. How can we justify the continued and even increased discounts when Brexit should have sounded the death knell for this incondictable system? The approval of the stimulus package to national parliaments will finally open the debate on the principle of subsidiarity. Why would a European plan be more effective than a series of national plans? This trompe l'oeil agreement actually hides a Europe undermined by the federalists, who are putting forward their deadly project for the nations.

name: David Cormand (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are relieved because we have avoided the worst, namely a non-agreement that would have aggravated the crisis we are going through. But like many pro-Europeans, I have in my mouth a taste of ash. What for? Politically, we have seen national selfishness confront each other. The European political imagination can no longer be that of free and undistorted competition between the nations that make up the Union. The inadequacies of the multi-year budget are glaring: the virtual absence of own resources deprives the Union of any real capacity for action, the governance of the Stimulus Fund hurts our idea of democracy. Finally, given the slope chosen, that of the sacrifice of ecological objectives, the fledgling European Green Pact is likely to disappear without a bang in the mirages of the resilience plan, which looks like a classic recovery plan. We will be told that we have acted urgently, but we must understand that if we find ourselves with our backs to the wall today, it is because, for too long, the choices made enshrine the victory of the short term at the expense of the future. The Europe of small steps forward is now preparing Europe for the great leap backwards and threatening the very survival of the European idea. We are not, as I have heard, the twenty-eighth voice of Europe, we are the first voice of Europe because we are the representatives of the European people. It is time to listen to Parliament's word.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Madam President, Honourable President of the European Commission, Honourable President of the Council, the VMRO Delegation will not support either the agreement or the resolution we are currently discussing for several reasons. First, this agreement is directly contrary to the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. All of you who promote the rule of law agree to breach the treaties. I can't understand, and I can't accept this hypocrisy and this duplicity. Secondly, you take out a loan from our children, you take out a loan that will pay it in 30 years our children without asking them about it, because there is no way. What's more, some of this loan will be handed out as grants, and the rest will be given as loans, but they will all be paid for and returned.  Dear Madam President, grants, donated money corrupt both governments and societies. It was, by the way, communism, which takes from those who work, and gives to those who need it. And we saw how it ended. And lastly, speculation about freedom, with the right to the rule of law. The rule of law means independent, free justice, no political interference, no political propaganda, no attempt to change societies, no attempt to change family relations, that is the rule of law.  Dear Mrs. Von der Leyen, dear Mr. Michel, who does not learn from history, is condemned to repeat it. You are today building a federal socialist Europe that is killing the European Union and the common market. Thank you.

name: François-Xavier Bellamy (PPE).
text: Madam President, Parliament does not accept this agreement. These are the finally forceful words of Article 3 that we will be voting on this morning. Of course, the solidarity of European countries was expected in the face of this historic crisis, and yet this recovery plan brings to a real question of wrong answers. Answers by a common debt of the European Union. Some, as we have heard, are already singing a historic moment. The epidemic from which we emerge, with its procession of mourning, and the unprecedented economic crisis that is before us should nevertheless oblige us not to rejoice. No one should have the right to make this tragedy an unexpected opportunity to resurrect old illusions to which the citizens of our countries have already repeatedly said no. What will they say when they discover that this stimulus package is in fact a federalist leap that did not say its name and to which they did not consent; when they realize that this unnecessary borrowing, because our countries can now easily access markets, has counterparties that our governments are careful not to talk to them about; when future generations will have to repay a debt ironically incurred in their name, without anyone knowing today how to return it? To snatch this common loan, we have paradoxically sacrificed the whole europe we really need. Food self-sufficiency has never been more crucial, and agricultural policy is down by $40 billion; the emerging crises make our strategic independence essential, and the European Defence Fund is halved; the ecological transition sees its funding fall from 30 to 10 billion, and even as the epidemic has revealed our weaknesses, European research is down by 13 billion and the health programme is reduced from 9.5 billion euros to one billion euros. A real historic agreement would have been, instead of getting excited because we have managed to further increase our debts, to prepare our future by profoundly reorienting the policies of the European Union in order to be able to make us stronger, to adapt our competition policies to rebuild our industry or to finally decide on this carbon tax which no one can achieve a real effect on the borders of the single market. , instead of pushing this debate further. This alone would allow for a real European recovery, and that is what our Parliament must tackle today.

name: Marek Belka (S&D).
text: – Madam President of the European Commission, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Schwab, for Mr President of the European Council, I would like to begin by thanking mr Today we are talking about how the Union is responding to the challenges of today – the pandemic – and tomorrow– the Union as a fiscal entity with its own resources. We are also talking about even more important issues, even those that are crucial to the existence of the European Union – the values that unite us, or at least unite us.  In my country, Poland, the issue of respect for the rule of law is at the heart of a heated discussion. There is a narrative from government circles that linking the rule of law to EU funds is only indirect and will in fact become a dead letter. The mechanism for linking the rule of law to the Funds and the concrete decisions taken by the Council of the European Union, where the qualified majority rule applies, will have to be approved by the European Council, where Poland will veto the unanimity rule there. Thus, please forgive me irony, Poland will defend its sovereignty, it will be able to violate the rule of law with impunity. Great success...  I therefore ask the President whether this narrative is correct or is it due to a misunderstanding of the conclusions adopted by the European Council? Or perhaps from consciously passing with the truth? The clear answer to this question is to blame for the Poles, but I think all Europeans too.

name: Nicola Beer (Renew).
text: Madam President, Madam President of the Commission, Charles Michel, I would like to thank the President-in-House for the work she has done. A Europe that inspires, not burdens, needs an ambitious EU budget, a budget that reflects our political priorities: smandies, innovation, foreign policy. Unfortunately, however, these items of a forward-looking modern budget have been torn apart in the trourie of national interests. Improvements need to be made here. It is precisely the pots for a Europe of technological leadership, a Europe as a real geopolitical player, which are endowed with very small coins, while agricultural posts are princely stocked. Why this concentration on possessions? Where are the ambitions, the courage for reform? Where is the departure into the future? How do we want jobs and training places, how do we want to secure and create prosperity? No, ladies and gentlemen, we have to work on this. It is certainly clear here that we will not achieve this with a Europe on the back. This cannot and must not be permanent. That is why the new relationship between loans and grants is also the right signal. In response to Mr Lamberts' criticism, it was governments with green participation that made this possible. More repayments, fewer gifts ... (Interruption) More repayments, Mr President, that is the signal for wise investment, coupled with promises of reform. More reforms, that is what Europe needs when it takes on common debt with a one-off response to a historic crisis.

name: Antonio Maria Rinaldi (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, over the last twenty years, Italy has been a net contributor to the European Union's coffers of around EUR 160 billion, if we confine ourselves to making just one arithmetic and non-capitalised sum and also including direct and indirect contributions to support countries in financial difficulty, including instruments such as the EDF and ESMA. For those who have really made the accounts, and not with colored lenses, perhaps blue with contour stars, it is very clear that this time too Italy, at the end of the entire complex Next Generation EU program, including the odious compensation due to the persistence of rebates, will continue to be a net contribution, even at the literally cost of slaughtering fiscally and socially , with primary leftovers, citizens and businesses, who would bring herds of furious rhinos to their knees. I therefore call on those who are over-the-board of wonderful advantages achieved by Italy at the European Council, including those who are now benefiting greatly from having become net importers of corporate tax offices in the euro area, to do well first and then to wip their mouths before making inappropriate remarks about my country. Mr von der Leyen, if a country defaults on its debt in recent years, who will pay for it the debts incurred by the Next Generation EU programme?

name: Helmut Geuking (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I, like many of you, of course, watched the summit at the weekend, and I was very frightened and wondered: has it not yet been said among the leaders of Europe that we are at the 21st century that we are ready to do so that European national states will never have the weight alone and will not have the power to assert themselves in this global world? , and that nation states can never cope with this crisis alone? This compromise, which was then reached at the end of the day, had light for me on the one hand, and shadows on the other. Shadow shaded in so far as it has not been shaped by the people of Europe and very essential elements – as we have already heard here today – have fallen victim to the red pencil. That is not right, there is an urgent need for improvements. Europe needs to be shaped by the people, and that requires these programmes that we have put in place, and much more is needed to do so. I wondered whether the leaders forgot the applause, or whether it had completely faded away, or whether they had not heard it at all, the applause that also reflects the will of the electorate, where we paid our respects to the people who work in systemically important professions – in health care. Hasn't that arrived? Where are the families, the victims of this crisis? Where will they be strengthened? I cannot see anything about this, and we urgently need to improve on this, because we owe it to the citizens of Europe. Otherwise, we are going in a direction that we all do not want to go. In other words, people must feel that Europe is good for them, and we urgently need to strengthen the victims of this crisis – families. That is my appeal to all those involved.

name: Charles Michel
text: President of the European Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank you for the various speeches that have been made. I would like once again to thank the whole of Parliament for the driving role, the visionary role that has been played over the last few weeks, the last few months. I would also like to thank the President of the Commission for the very strong cooperation. I would like to respond briefly to some of the points that have been addressed. The first one that I will highlight, and many have pointed out, is the determination, this time, to act quickly and to act strongly. We remember a financial crisis that was a demonstration that, when we acted too slowly and too little, the bill was all the heavier. The choice that was made in just a few weeks, at the start of a Commission proposal, was to mobilise to convince 27 Member States, 27 political leaders, each responsible to their national parliaments to move forward - and I dare say the formula - towards a Copernican evolution of the European project. What is on the table, with this MFF, and especially with this stimulus fund, following COVID-19, is transforming the way in which tomorrow the European Union will be able to close ranks, as soon as we make the choice to mobilise this debate on own resources. It is true that this is an old debate, it is not a new debate. This is an old political debate that has been the subject of an absolutely substantial step forward this time, and I am pleased that the European Parliament, the national parliaments, the Council and the European Council can continue to be engaged, because behind the question on these levies, they are linked to carbon at the borders, linked to the digital issue, linked to the financial issue. , there are fundamentally democratic debates, which deserve to be mobilized by our citizens. The 450 million European citizens must be involved in democratic processes at the national level, as well as at the European level. I also want to tell you that this act that is being done is, from my point of view, not an outcome, but the starting point. A lot of work, mobilization and energy will be needed to ensure that this paper agreement can be transformed in the European Council, which will give rise to passionate and exciting discussions with the European Parliament, that this can be transformed into real life. I said this in the introduction, and I repeat, it is not just a question of money, it is a question of values, principles and the direction we want to give to this European project which is mobilising us. This European project, which is a unique project, unprecedented in the history of the world: 450 million citizens, 27 different countries gathered by a common foundation of values, united by a common ambition to move forward, to ensure that there is more shared humanity, is the demonstration that has been made, I believe today. Finally, one last word, I heard the excesses, I heard the words, let's say, a little miserable, of the extremist parties represented here, so I measure well: you choose the retreat, you choose hatred, you choose the separation, you choose the rejection. We choose tolerance, openness, gathering. It is a sad day for you, it is a happy day for Europe and for Europeans. (Applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: Thank you, Mr Michel, also for your participation in this extraordinary plenary today. Let us resume with our speeches.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – Mr President, let me start by saying to President Michel that I congratulate the Council for this historical agreement. But it is an irony that when we finally have real, true European money, we are going to spend it, basically, in national envelopes and national programmes, not in a European–wide big programme. The very serious crisis that health has brought us today, in particular, demands a tribute to the dead, to the sick, to the recovered, to health professionals, but this crisis is also a very serious economic and social crisis, and so it is essential to say that this agreement is a historic agreement, but it poses a question: how will it be applied? National governments now have no excuses, they have the means to respond to the crisis, citizens, businesses, workers. Finally, and as for the MFF, I want to say that we are disappointed, especially because there is no major programme for health, and especially because we despise research and Erasmus+, and that is why we are on Parliament's side in conditioning this programme. We will only approve the MFF if these defects are corrected. A final word for my Fellow Portuguese Socialist, who spoke here at the Conference on the Future of Europe, but unfortunately it has been the Portuguese the most reluctant and the one that has most blocked the future of Europe in the Council. And he spoke of values and rights, but it was Prime Minister António Costa who came to defend the total separation between the recovery fund and the rule of law.

name: Heléne Fritzon (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Yes, Europe faces major challenges that we must also solve jointly. We need both a modern long-term budget, which prioritises climate and gender equality, and a recovery package linked to the current crisis. And of course it should go to the green transition. It is therefore very gratifying that, after five long days, the EU Heads of State or Government have managed to reach an agreement on both the long-term budget and the recovery package. It is a historic success. A negotiation is always about giving and taking and we know that there are different views and wills in the Member States. This is also the case here in Parliament. Now they have assumed their responsibilities. Let's take our responsibility.  We need a Europe, a Europe that takes the lead in the climate challenge, which is pushing for an equal and equal Europe and which stands up for the rule of law in all Member States. Not in 25, not in 26 – but in 27 Member States you should stand up for the rule of law. That is how we together build a strong Union for future generations. And then why are we doing this? Yes, I do it for the sake of my children and grandchildren and their future.

name: Dragoș Pîslaru (Renew).
text: – Mr President, we all heard what the EU leaders want. Now, it’s our role in this House to discuss what citizens want, and, in particular, let us hear what the next generation wants. We name it, we promote it, but we do not listen to it. We see how programme such as Erasmus+, Youth Guarantee, Horizon and Digital Europe are cut or left unfunded in a survival mode in a feeble multiannual financial budget; 90% of the Next Generation EU funds will finance the Recovery and Resilience Facility, the largest EU programme in history, which will help us renew Europe. As a co-rapporteur on this file, I wish to make a pledge. The Recovery and Resilience Facility will be an instrument for the next generation. I will advocate as part of the Parliament position to have, within the Recovery and Resilience Facility, a pillar for reforms and investment designed for the next generation, for youth and children. We will repair and prepare the Union for the future only by having the next generation on board, not only asking them to pay the bill, but to let them have a voice. To our youth, to our children: at EU level, Parliament is, and will be, your voice.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The European Council reached a difficult compromise on the new budget, a budget that is very important for the recovery of the EU economy after the crisis that has hit us. For this it is due to the participants – all participants – to thank. I think that prime minister Mateusz Morawiecki's role in reaching this agreement deserves special recognition. The critical voices that are heard here at the conclusions of the summit are not only an exaggeration, but also sometimes hypocritical. What my fellow MEPs, unfortunately also those in Polish, call the rule of law protection mechanism, is an attempt to create a non-treaty tool to influence Member States, a mechanism that is not based on facts and data, but on sympathies and dislikes of national governments. The facts are that all the new laws that are adopted in Poland are compatible with existing law and with European treaties. Poland is therefore a law-abiding country. There is no doubt about that, but some in this House would like to use the rule of law instrument to pressure disliked prime ministers or disliked governments.  Poland uses European funds exemplaryly in accordance with the Treaties and Polish law. This should be the only criterion that should be used in such discussions. The Council took a decision on the basis of such conditions. I hope that Parliament will not spoil the outcome of these difficult negotiations by making unrealistic demands. More than ever, Europeans need cooperation today, not bare disputes.

name: Kris Peeters (PPE).
text: Mr President, a huge step forward has been made in recent days. With the political commitment of the Heads of State or Government to a European recovery fund and a multi-annual budget, we can reinvest in our European future and in our European economy. Such a European recovery fund is unprecedented in terms of size.  The so-called "Next Generation EU" plan consists of €390 billion in funds and €360 billion in loans. On the one hand, funds avoid the derailing of the debt ratio of the southern Member States, and on the other hand, loans ensure that each country pays a fair share of its own recovery. The €5 billion Brexit fund is also necessary and good for both our country Belgium and the EU.  But the work isn't finished. The multi-annual budget as it stands is making a big cut in research and development, just as we are looking for a vaccine for corona and now that we are making fighting cancer a priority. Investment in research and development and the Horizon Europe programme are desperately needed if the EU is to move the future forward. I also strongly disapprove of the large savings on health programmes, Erasmus+ and defence. The EU cannot acquire strategic autonomy without full-fledged defence cooperation.  Negotiations between the Council and the European Parliament are now underway, with a second wave of coronation coming at us and a hard Brexit becoming increasingly likely. Time is running out, but we can only see that the budget agreement can and must be improved.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D).
text: Mr President, my country has not been very good in Europe in recent weeks. Captain of the stingy four, you should be proud of it. Prime Minister Rutte's short-sighted self-interest should really have been different as far as the PvdA is concerned. Nevertheless, the PvdA is pleased that there is an agreement. We can now tackle this crisis together, and that is good for the Europeans, which is good for unity. It shows unity, strength and added value of Europe to the rest of the world.  However, the proposed budget is actually one of old wine in new bags. Old priorities are not addressed and new priorities, such as youth unemployment, health, climate and science, did not appear to be a priority. A missed opportunity, precisely because of this corona crisis. Not to mention the weak link between EU funds and the rule of law. Mr President, I would say that we are on our way, but we are really starting now.

name: Ondřej Knotek (Renew).
text: – Mr President, the Agreement from the European Council gives us all hope that we will eventually emerge stronger from this situation. The leaders of the EU countries have really fulfilled their role and deserve our thanks. I think it is important to mention that all European institutions should fulfil their role in order to maintain public support. On the agreement itself, let me, as coordinator of the REGI Committee, I am not entirely in favour of reducing the allocation for the Just Transition Fund and REACT-EU. On the contrary, I very much welcome the strengthening of the role of cohesion policy. The policy that sustains and creates new jobs today. Let me also thank Commissioner Elise Ferreira, who is responsible for cohesion, for her excellent work.  Finally, let me stress that European funds, which should be spent precisely on climate action, should be open to all possible effective, available technologies, including nuclear energy.

name: Karlo Ressler (PPE).
text: – Dear President, colleagues and colleagues, at an unprecedented time of health and economic crisis, after a dramatic spring, an unusual summer and an uncertain rest of the year, the Political Agreement of the European Council is a positive message. The message of both responsibility and togetherness that Europe needs today. Some countries, economic sectors, but also generations, are more affected than others, and that is why it was crucial to avoid deepening social and economic disparities. For my country, Croatia, but also for much of Europe, concrete solidarity represents a great opportunity for faster economic recovery and empowerment. With digital and green transformation, reducing disparities is a prerequisite for a new generation Europe. At the same time, it is also clear that this is only the beginning. A next-generation Europe is only possible by investing even more strongly in proven successful European programmes, research, education, digital Europe in everything that is forward-looking. As the only European body elected, the European Parliament can build on this good proposal with a strong European perspective and make it even better. Together, we must show that Europe is ready for historic steps when it is needed most, for all generations and for all Member States.

name: Pierre Larrouturou (S&D).
text: (Start of intervention off microphone) ... health, climate and employment without asking for more from national budgets. The digital tax is fine, but it is $2 billion a year. Two billion. The plastic tax is fantastic, but it is $5 billion, and it will decrease. The best solution, the one that can bring in the most money and bring together the most countries, is the financial transaction tax. The Council referred to this in its conclusions. Well done! But it's not enough to talk about it, we need an agreement, and we need it this year. Despite Brexit and the crisis, a financial transaction tax can bring in $50 billion a year. In 2011, the Barroso Commission proposed a directive, and this directive, despite Brexit and the crisis, can bring in 50 billion each year. Fifty billion euros is 15 billion to pay down the common debt and 35 billion more for health, climate and jobs. This is the position of the Social Democrat group: this is a solution for a more ambitious budget, without one euro more from the Member States. The Council said it was a priority, Germany said it was one of its priorities. I am very happy about that. I am rapporteur of the 2021 budget and, as a citizen, as a Member of Parliament, I will not be able to accept a budget if we have not had an agreement on the FTT this year. We want an extra $50 billion for health, climate and jobs.

name: Sophia in ‘t Veld (Renew).
text: – Mr President, before I start my intervention, I would like to say that I find it regrettable that the leadership of the Commission and the Council have a habit of leaving before the end of the debate. For such an important debate, I would expect everybody to be here until the end. Today is a birthday. It’s the birthday of the European Coal and Steel Community, and in the 1951 founding Treaty of Paris, it gave the High Authority the power to levy taxes and to borrow money and budget decisions were taken by majority. Now, let that sink in. The government leaders at the time had the vision and the courage to take a big leap forward for future generations. Today’s debate is not about money or figures; it’s about how we want to shape our European society and make it fit for the future. It’s about the choice between old Europe and new Europe. Rebates are old Europe – actually, 1984, when the Berlin Wall still divided Europe. Investing in research, climate policies and the rule of law, that’s new Europe. Last year, over 200 million Europeans gave us a mandate. They voted with hopes and expectations for the future. Parliament has the power and we have a duty to use it. Let’s take that leap forward.

name: Presidente. –
text: I will make your point.

name: Andrey Novakov (PPE).
text: – Mr President, dear Commissioner, dear representatives of the Council, since there weren't too many colleagues who said it, I'm going to do it: thank you for steering the ship during that five-day storm. You deserve, at least, respect for your strength and for what you achieved. Of course, what you've achieved is not perfect. Your agreement is not perfect, so there is also a European Parliament that will try to make it one.  There are things that are difficult to explain, such as the promise to overcome the COVID crisis together and reduce money, for example for ReactEU. Like promising a cleaner environment and shrinking the money under the Fair Transition Fund, which should support the mining industry in Europe. These are things that we will fight against, help increase money for Erasmus students. I'm sure you'il understand. In the end, however, I think that what we have taken on has much greater value, it is much more important. Although the European Parliament has waited almost 600 days for this agreement, we are ready more than ever to make it wonderful.  At the end of each day, when we kiss our children good night, we promise them a better morning. Now is the time to deliver on our promise, and with all due respect, the only policy that saved lives during this crisis was cohesion. Not a cent should be reduced from it, we must support it, we must also support the fund that will overcome the COVID crisis. That's what the citizens expect from us. This parliament exists for them, not the other way around. Thank you.

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Europe, with the recovery fund, decides to take the reins of its destiny: joint taxes, debt in common, to build a common future, which is how societies build it.  This time our reforms are going to be betting on Europeans, investing in them; for a more competitive, digital, green economy, with quality jobs; to bet on a more resilient industry and, of course, with more inclusive, fairer growth that makes us converge.  Somehow, we learn from our past mistakes. We're not going to rescue any country. This time what we rescue is Europe and its values, which give us meaning: collective ambition and solidarity.  It's taken a long time to get to the recovery fund. This Parliament has contributed to this ⸺and many governments, such as Spanish⸺. But the price to be paid has also been high: a regrettable proposal for a Union budget.  And that is why we demand, as the co-responsible authority for the budget, a Union budget at the level of our challenges and, in particular, with budget items that are in line with the demands of our citizens.

name: Lídia Pereira (PPE).
text: – Mr President, seven months ago we were awake to a new reality. We have seen with our own eyes the devastating effect of a little-known virus until then, and the speed with which it has spread around the world is only comparable to the speed of the very fear it has generated. One after the other, all the countries of our Union were being affected and in all, without exception, many lives were lost. Fear and the need to stop the virus have immobilized our factories, closed our schools and for months left our lives on hold. But Europe has not stopped. Once again Europe has been able to come up with the challenge, silencing with actions and decisions the populists who are announcing the end of our European Union over and over again. I particularly welcome the decision to move forward with the rate on disposable plastic as the Union's own new recipe, a small step of great significance for the new generations. However, it is not all good news: the Council has given up an instrument for the solvency of enterprises, very important aid, real emergency aid, and has forced cuts in Horizon Europe, the Erasmus programme and the Fair Transition Fund. The happy name NextGenerationEU thus loses part of its meaning. Unfortunately governments have chosen to give reason to the Basque philosopher Daniel Innerarity when he says that, too often, the future is the dustbin of the present.

name: Udo Bullmann (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his work We are deeply concerned about our international responsibilities. The reconstruction programme does not provide humanitarian aid, and the medium-term financial framework has been shortened when it comes to development cooperation. Solidarity threatens to suffer, especially at a time when our partners are particularly in need of it. This needs to be improved, it needs to be changed. We Social Democrats are working for a good development of these programmes: for good work, for social context, for economic renewal. We have set the course for this, in Germany and in Europe. But one thing is always clear: the rights of citizens in Warsaw and Budapest do not have a price tag, they are not for sale, either today or tomorrow, nor on the day that the vote on the medium-term financial framework takes place in this House.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The European Council's late compromise is the start of negotiations with the European Parliament. These negotiations are urgently needed because we must not accept the renationalisation, the lack of responsibility for the future and the plethora of declarations of intent, while at the same time unanimity, but must improve the situation and the result. The European Union is not an ATM, nor is we a bazaar. We are a community of laws and values. We want to strengthen European democracy. We want to be a credible community of the future, and we are responsible for the people and of togetherness and the future, not of party strategies and not of right-wing populism and national populism, which is unfortunately growing in our Member States. We need courage, decency, responsibility and attitude. President Michel's speeches here are different from the communication of the historic result of 750 billion – yes, that is historic – by many – too many – Heads of State or Government in the Member States, because it is national populist and not shaped by European responsibility and this historic result. I would therefore like to make it very clear that we in the European Parliament are in favour of this: no decision without the European Civic Chamber, no money in the event of a violation of European law and our values, withdrawal of all cuts at the expense of our common objectives in education, research, security, climate investment and social cohesion, the introduction of a rule of law mechanism and own resources for a binding repayment plan with nooks and crannies. Unanimity must be fell in order for European democracy to become stronger.

name: Marc Angel (S&D).
text: – Mr President, finding an agreement and a common answer to an unprecedented crisis in Europe is good news. Yes, the deal is historic, but only the part of the Recovery Fund – Next Generation EU – which includes a big part of grants and also communitarisation of debt. This is solidarity and a better answer to a crisis than in 2008. However, when it comes to the MFF, which is supposed to make Europe more resilient, more social, more modern and climate-friendlier, this is bad news for the next generation and not historic. As socialists, we cannot accept the cuts in future-oriented programmes. We cannot and will not accept the watering-down of the rule of law and, therefore, it is good that in this resolution we added fundamental rights and democracy. I deeply regret that the rebates have not been abolished. Here the Council missed an opportunity to move us out of the net payer discussion in Europe. Europe is more than giving and taking! Today, we as Members of the European Parliament, the only directly elected EU institution, write history too by voting in favour of this resolution, where we welcome the Recovery Fund but we clearly state that this MFF is not enough. Not enough when it comes to finances and not enough when it comes to defending the rule of law and democracy. This Parliament will not swallow bitter pills. Europe deserves more.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: Mr President, the leaders of the European Union have taken a historic step in approving joint borrowing to deal with the biggest recession since the war. It is now necessary for these resources to be coordinated in order for the single market and our economies to be greener, more digital and more resilient. Of course, this historic step is based on a historic compromise from which we as a Parliament cannot accept the decoupling of funding from the rule of law, the reduction of funds for research, health and education, the reduction of funds for the Fair Transition Fund, which the regions of Western Macedonia and Megalopolis so badly need. We hope that this will change in the negotiation.  Ladies and gentlemen, these hours in the Mediterranean are becoming scenes of unprecedented tension under Turkey's responsibility. Turkey, a candidate country for membership of the European Union, threatens Greece's sovereign rights, has issued NAVTEX, aiming to conduct seismic surveys on Greece's continental shelf.
