Turkey violates the exclusive economic zone of Cyprus. Turkey is challenging France. Turkey is violating the arms trade in Libya. It offends the values of Western civilization, turning the World Heritage Site, Hagia Sophia, into a mosque.  Ladies and gentlemen, we are now calling for the list of European Union sanctions against Turkey to be drawn up immediately. It is the only way for the Union to send a clear and clear message that it does not tolerate the sovereign rights of its members being violated, that it does not tolerate threats at its borders by tooling people who are suffering. It is time for the European Union to take its place as a player on the international foreign policy chessboard. Now, any tolerance in Turkey undermines the strength of the European Union. It undermines our common future.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this European Council will certainly enter European history because it has taken the right direction for our future. The unity of Europe has been chosen, solidarity between states has been chosen, responsibility has been chosen to tackle together, with common instruments, not only the economic crisis but also the problems of citizens' lives – work, health – finally revealing europe's social soul. Finally, it has been understood that if a country falls sooner or later everyone can fall. And I have to say that the nationalists and populists, including from my own country, Italy, where they believe they are still strong, have no arguments at the moment in their battle against Europe. But there is a great deal of appreciation for this result, so much is strong, I have to say, disappointment and also rejection – as far as I am concerned, but not only me, so many voices have been raised here – for an MFF that is inconsistent, contradictory and perhaps detrimental to the objectives that the Recovery Plan proposes. I really do not understand: you cannot cut culture, education and research: I say this to President Michel, who is not here, but to those who listen for him. You can't cut the search. I would remind you that we have spent the last few months hanging from the lips of scientists, doctors and researchers to understand how to behave, how to survive. And even today our future, our life, the economy depend on the choices, decisions and results of ongoing research on vaccines, drugs, etc. We all praised together the health workers and researchers who, even with inadequate facilities, with inadequate salaries, carried on, we said "heroically", their work. We cannot stop now: the MFF is insufficient. Mr President, you, who have worked so hard, even if you have not been thanked today, for this result, I am sure that you will also take on board, on behalf of this Parliament, a better result for the MFF.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. First of all, I would like to express my sincere thanks to you for holding this extraordinary sitting and for actually interrupting some of you's well-deserved holidays. However, it is also appropriate for the occasion that we are indeed getting into the gears here quickly. In any case, it has taken a long time for the European Council to clarify its position on negotiations. We now have a result. I share your criticism of the design, particularly the MFF. There is certainly something that I hope can be tightened up in the negotiations, especially those areas that cannot be compensated for by Next Generation EU. When I think, for example, of foreign policy, we have explained quite massively and have often discussed here in this House how important it is, for example, to take action in the neighbourhood – in Africa – originally – and still valid – for reasons of combating migration, but also now when it comes to ensuring that in other parts of the world– provided that we have a drug. , we have a vaccine – these funds can also be made available. This is only possible if there is also a corresponding budget. I therefore think that there is an opportunity here to make further adjustments in these areas in particular. You have mentioned the rule of law very often today. There are – and I believe, Mrs Piri, that one of you who said this – different interpretations. That's the essence: everyone goes home and sees what they want to see. But what counts is what is ultimately written on the paper, and above all, what is finally adopted. In this respect, there is a political statement. But now it is a question of putting this into legislation, and you are part of this discussion and, finally, of this decision. As far as own resources are concerned, I would like to thank you again today for your strong support. But I think the road is mapped out. It has always been necessary to see first what, at the end of the day, is actually, so to speak, the order of magnitude that must not only be raised on the capital market, but also repaid. On the basis of this, we as the Commission can now go into detailed planning – and we have also been instructed in this direction. What kind of new own resources can there be? The conclusions give some indications, and Parliament also has its ideas. I believe that they are all to be collected, and then it is also necessary to make a solid analysis of needs. Some of your own revenue streams can be designed and decided and implemented more quickly. Others simply need more time because of the complexity when I think, for example, of the carbon border tax and the corresponding mechanism. This is a legal exercise, and it is not easy to do so. This will also take some time. However, you can assume that the Commission, if I may say so, is determined to make proposals here as soon as possible. Again, thank you very much! I believe that what has been achieved over the last four days has rightly been described by some of you as a historic decision. With all the downsides that exist in these decisions. But I think it has already been shown, and I was involved there more than ten years ago: indeed, the European Union did not get off to a pace at the time of the financial and economic crisis, as is currently the case. We should also keep this in mind. And that is why I make my final appeal: I understand – and it is perfectly clear and also comprehensible – the need and also – I believe – the right of the European Parliament to be more closely involved in the whole decision-making process and also in the question of how the money must be used in the years to come. I would just ask that we also have a quick discussion and also a quick decision-making. The real thing here is that time is of the essence, and we must not forget that if you have taken decisions, then we also need the decisions of the Member States. Twenty-three national parliaments must ratify this, i.e. all The Member States as a whole. This is a process that usually takes many, many months. We are being asked to do so ideally this year, so that we can indeed help European citizens and European entrepreneurs at the beginning of the year and not only in the middle or towards the end of the year. Here too, I believe, European solidarity is necessary. Once again, thank you very much!

name: Presidente. –
text: We are at the end of this extraordinary plenary debate. The next plenary session will be in September. We have all experienced, ladies and gentlemen, a special moment in our lives and in the life of our institution. I wanted to thank everyone: all the political groups, parliament's administration, the interpreters' booths. These have been very difficult months, we have done everything we can to make Parliament work and, with the functioning of Parliament, we have made the European Union work. It was an extraordinary achievement, for which I must thank you, for the sacrifices that everyone has made, for their patience. We all wanted more but everything was done with the tools we had. Now our work continues, Parliament and its work will continue. It will be nice to be back in Strasbourg, which is one of our cities. Thank you, thank you all. I have received two motions for resolutions pursuant to Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place today. Written declarations (Rule 171)

name: Magdalena Adamowicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The european Council's agreement on the eu's multiannual budget and the Covid-19 aid package is very important news for a Europe struggling with the severe effects of the pandemic. However, this does not mean that the outcome of the negotiations is fully satisfactory. Indeed, it is difficult to accept a significant reduction in investment in climate protection, research, education or, finally, health. The coronavirus pandemic has shown us all how important it is to strengthen Europe's health security and prepare the Community for possible health crises that may arise in the future. It is also particularly noteworthy that, for the first time in history, the dissuasing of EU funds has been conditional on respect for the rule of law. In this situation, it is necessary to increase the possibility for beneficiaries, in particular local authorities and NGOs, to make use of EU funds directly. For these reasons, the European Parliament cannot accept the agreement presented by the European Council. Any reservations and doubts must be resolved during the negotiations between the European Parliament and the Council of the EU representing the Member States.

name: Christine Anderson (ID)
text: Writing. – Paymaster Germany: It was only through a dirty backroom deal that the 27 Member States were able to agree on the new common EU budget of EUR 1.8 BILLION. For example, Austria will receive a discount of around 4.0 billion by 2027. The Netherlands is given 1.9 billion and Sweden around 1.1 billion a year. While the heads of state of these thrifty countries have thus been able to achieve real success for their citizens because of their enviable tenacity, our country is going the other way. Merkel-Germany formally begged to be allowed to cover the costs of others. The result: an additional EUR 10 billion per year now adds up to around EUR 40 billion per year. Even before this deal, Germany paid 13.4 billion euros more into the EU budget than it subsequently got out of. While our "people's kicks" cheer German taxpayers' money, 2.8 million children and young people in this country have to live in poverty. This also applies to countless single parents, precarious workers, transfer benefit recipients and pensioners in poverty. At the same time, in addition to a low retirement age, Italy also guarantees its citizens interest rates of 1.4 percent above the inflation rate through so-called "patriot" bonds, while German savers continue to look into the tube. Germany is not the stupid milking cow of the EU and the money of its hard-working taxpayers must therefore be used exclusively for German interests!

name: Andrus Ansip (Renew)
text: Writing. – Ursula von der Leyen, President of the European Commission, said in a speech that in the previous crisis many young people had to leave their homes and that inequality between Member States worsened, this time we would act differently and better. I do not agree with the argument that, in the previous crisis, the European Union as a whole acted wrongly or badly. I consider the implementation of austerity measures in the previous crisis to be fully justified. The current European Commission stands on the shoulders of Mr Barroso and Jean-Claude Juncker. If austerity measures had not been implemented in the previous crisis, we would not be able to implement economic stimulus measures comparable to those of the United States and China in the current crisis. I welcome the agreement reached by the Council on the multiannual budget and the relaunch of the economy. In order to emerge from global competition as a winner, negotiations with the European Parliament must be conducted as soon as possible. Investment in research, health and climate objectives should be increased during the negotiations. The negotiations should pursue a common digital tax and the introduction of a carbon cap.

name: Anna-Michelle Asimakopoulou (PPE)
text: in writing. – Finally … we have a deal! Finally … the Council, after copious negotiations reached a mutually acceptable solution and a deal that will determine the future course of the European Union. Finally, you understood what the European Parliament was telling you all along, in response to voices of our citizens across Europe, that we must rise to the occasion and face the challenges created by the pandemic with courage, solidarity and ‘more Europe’. Finally, you listened to Leaders of Member States, like the Prime Minister of Greece, Kyriakos Mitsotakis, who told you that we are facing an unprecedented economic crisis and we don’t have the leeway to appear divided or weak. Finally, you reached a compromise and made a courageous leap towards a more united Europe. Finally, you gave my country, Greece, a historic opportunity, after ten years of austerity, injustice and pain, to move on with the necessary reforms to achieve its productive reconstruction. We must complete this ambitious effort quickly for the benefit of European citizens. With solidarity, cohesion and procedures that safeguard the democratic processes guaranteed by the European Parliament and with respect of the principles and values of a united Europe. Finally… together, let us take Europe to the next level.

name: Dominique Bilde (ID)
text: In writing. This stimulus package is a scam for France, which is still paying a high price for the rebates granted to the so-called "frugal" states: 7.6 billion euros per year that will benefit the Netherlands, Sweden, Austria, Denmark and Germany, this total discount having historically been financed 30% by France. France, already the second largest net contributor to the European budget, would therefore receive 40 billion euros out of the 390 billion direct subsidies. A market of dupes, since it will actually have to repay about 66 billion euros. Except, of course, to achieve by then the famous 'European tax', which is neither desirable nor realistic: the 'digital tax' stumbles in particular on the Irish opposition. That France fails to defend its interests can only be blamed on its leaders. Thus, the European and international press has, alas, seen right by sacking the stubborn Dutch Prime Minister who won these bitter negotiations. But this debacle is only the first avatar of the intractable financial difficulties that are looming for the European Union, following the departure of the United Kingdom, and that an illusory European federalism will only precipitate.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – Indeed, the Member States have succeeded in finding a complex and difficult agreement, which shows that, despite the difficulties, Europe is able to unite and seek compromises. For the first time in history, Europe has agreed on joint efforts to share the financial burden. Extraordinary challenges require extraordinary solutions, and the common debt mechanism is an expression of European solidarity, where the commitment to repay debt will be based on the EU's own resources system, rather than lying on the shoulders of our citizens. However, concerns remain about the multiannual financial perspective, which is extremely important, especially at this difficult time. The multiannual financial perspective must focus on the overall recovery and growth of the EU. We cannot justify budget cuts in the social sphere and significantly reduce funding for programmes such as Horizon, Erasmus+, ESF+, Digital Europe and others that are vital for the long-term and sustainable growth of the EU. As the Chair of our group has said, Europe is not only sharing solidarity, but also responsibility, and we must ensure that the rule of law and respect for fundamental human rights are ensured in the Member States so that the EU as a whole moves forward in a unified manner, respecting and ensuring fundamental values.

name: Milan Brglez (S&D)
text: Writing. – The political agreement of the EU Heads of State and Government represents a fundamental turning point that allows the process of further building the EU and therefore I welcome it as such.  However, in several places, the latter does not have sufficient confidence in what this construction, the foundations of which are being laid down by the next Multiannual Financial Framework together with the recovery plan, actually be. The political discourse of the EU institutions is dominated by the view that it is starting with the reconstruction of the EU, which will be built for future generations. At the same time, the European Council, through its decisions on financial cuts, has intervened precisely in those areas of the budget that would provide a solid foundation for future generations of Europeans.  It is difficult to imagine an EU that will be fairer, more unified, resilient, green-oriented and competitive if funding is planned for areas (and programmes) such as employment (Just Transition Fund), youth (Erasmus+), health (EU4health), environment, digitalisation, research and development (LIFE+, Digital Europe, Horizon Europe) and infrastructure (InvestEU).  However, the political aspirations of the leaders of certain countries to neglect certain civilisational achievements of European integration are of particular concern. A Europe of future generations, based on the principles of democracy, human rights and social pluralism, may only be a utopia in the future if the EU does not take a strong and responsible stance towards the importance of respect for the rule of law in its Member States.

name: Joachim Stanisław Brudziński (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The longest-ever European Council has ended. I am convinced that this summit has been a success for all 27 EU leaders. It is not only Poland and Hungary that have reason to be satisfied. That is the ability to compromise so that all parties feel that they have succeeded.  The outcome of the summit is also a personal success for Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki. A success that translates into billions of zlotys, which in the near budgetary perspective will Polish flow. This will be the largest transfer of EU funds Polish in history. Here I would like to make a very strong point: Poland is not against the rule of law. We have respected and obeyed the law, but we strongly oppose the fact that, in an unspecified way, not rooted in any legislation, in any EU treaty this abstract mechanism is used to exert pressure on individual countries, especially those whose leaders come from outside this Brussels establishment today.  The conviction that the rule of law is repentant of those who come from the left or from the Brussels salon is repentant. If parties such as Fidesz and PiS come to power, there is talk of fascism, of dictatorship. Meanwhile, the only dictatorship that the EU can threaten today is the dictatorship of political correctness and the belief that there are countries in Europe that are allowed more and those that are allowed less.

name: Sara Cerdas (S&D)
text: in writing. – The COVID-19 pandemic has exposed the weaknesses of the European Union and identified areas and sectors that need investment and complementary attention. The proposal adopted this week by the European Council has specificities that should concern us in the context of a pandemic, such as cuts in the Commission's proposal on health and research programmes. It is essential to invest in health, science and technology. The new MFF should be an opportunity to invest in strategic areas, not forgetting programmes that contribute to the development and cohesion of EU regions and Member States. The system needs to be recast in line with the principles of the European Ecological Pact, which is sustainable and aligned with the digital transition and always putting people first. For a more resilient European Union that responds to the needs of the immediate and considers future generations.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. – The COVID-19 pandemic, with its dramatic costs in human, economic and social lives, imposes a collective duty of solidarity on the EU and its Member States. The European Council has finally reached an historic agreement, accepting a Recovery Fund to get the economy back on track as requested by the European Parliament, and accepting the principle of joint debt. However, we must continue to work towards the adoption of a 2021-2027 MFF that really lives up to European objectives. Parliament must be immediately and fully involved in the pursuit of this result in order to improve the Council's agreement. In particular, it is necessary to introduce a new system of the Union's own resources, the only instrument capable of safeguarding the EU budget and alleviating the pressure on national finances and European citizens. In addition, the EU budget must be protected against fraud and corruption, increasing transparency and controls, and against systematic violations of the principles enshrined in Art. 2 TEU, through an effective European mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. In dealing with an unprecedented crisis, the institutions must give priority to people, combining the economic, social and ecological aspects of every action, so that no European citizen is left behind.

name: Johan Danielsson (S&D)
text: Written. We have a compromise on the table and now it is important that we focus on managing it as well as possible. I know that some would have liked the recovery plan to consist solely of loans, while others would have liked even more funding. But now the scope of the fund and the next long-term budget is set. For me, there are two things that are of particular importance as we move forward. Firstly, that the mechanism linked to the rule of law should work. If Viktor Orbán can extract billions in aid while continuing to dismantle democracy in his native Hungary, it will seriously risk and weaken support for EU cooperation in Sweden and other countries. Why should we pay to keep the Orbán regime in power? Secondly, we must ensure that the EUR 672.5 billion now to be distributed to the Member States is actually used to rethink our societies to meet the climate challenge. If this does not happen, this will at best be a missed opportunity and, at worst, something that will fundamentally damage europe.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – More than the deep fractures and contradictions that run through the EU, the European Council meeting highlighted the very nature of an intrinsically generating integration process of inequalities and asymmetries, in which capitalist competition in the single market prevails over any prospect of solidarity between States, which in practice is confirmed as non-existent. The Conclusions of the European Council, initially drawn by Germany and France and subsequently welcoming the pressure and impositions of other major beneficiaries of the single market and the euro, lay down even more unfavourable conditions for Portugal and other "cohesion" countries. On the one hand, a more significant cut in the Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027 is confirmed, with implications for cohesion and agriculture funding. Some of the main beneficiaries of the integration guarantee a substantial increase in the discount to their contributions, which they already benefited from. On the other hand, the so-called Recovery Fund is reduced, particularly in its "grants" component. At the same time, mechanisms are being made to establish increased EU interference in the implementation of investment options and other sovereign decisions of the Member States. This is unacceptable additional pressure to link the instruments now approved - Budget and Recovery Fund - to the imposition of the EU's neoliberal prescription.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. – The multiannual financial framework adopted by the European Council and the "Next Generation EU" recovery fund are of historical importance. The Heads of State or Government have succeeded in reinforcing European solidarity and adopted the most environmentally friendly budget in the history of the Union. Over the next seven years, the European Union and the Member States will spend more than EUR 500 billion to achieve the 2050 climate neutrality target. The agreement makes a significant contribution to the achievement of the objectives set out in the Green Agreement and is also the world's first 'green' crisis management package. It is also a positive step that Member States can have a significant amount of resources to meet the greenhouse gas emission reduction targets for 2030 and 2050. In this way, it will be possible for Member States to develop their energy mixes in an economically and socially sustainable way to facilitate the green transition. In order to meet climate ambitions and make effective use of financial instruments, it is also worth taking into account good practices in the Member States. Such a good example Hungary committed to a clean, smart and energy policy that enhances people's well-being. As a result, it has been able to reduce emissions of harmful substances and reduce household energy prices in addition to a steadily growing economy over the last decade.

name: Robert Hajšel (S&D)
text: Writing. – Reaching an agreement at the summit is good news for the European economy, but cutting some essential instruments from the EC's original proposal and the EP's demands brings the agreement into a more unfavourable light. A number of aspects that we considered essential were not being pushed through, both in the multiannual financial framework and in the unprecedented EUR 750 billion recovery package. Significantly less resources are to go to health, science, research and education, to create own resources or to combat climate change. These are all key areas where citizens expect an enhanced EU presence. Although we have been instructed by the corona crisis to call for the creation of a health union, cutting the budget to a fifth is a significant step backwards. Apart from the tax on non-recyclable plastics, none of the proposed own resources have been introduced into the EU budget, such as carbon duty, digital customs duties, a financial transaction tax. As rapporteur and shadow rapporteur for the two instruments included in the recovery plan, I consider the misrepresentation of the Budget of the Just Transition Fund from 40 to 17.5 billion to be bad news for the regions of the Member States concerned and the complete elimination of the financing of the Solvency Facility as an unfavourable signal to corona crisis-damaged firms. The EU must be able to show citizens that it is ready to bring real solutions, so I believe that the EP's voice will also be able to reinforce some of the key measures.

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – On 17-21 July, a historic European Council was held to discuss the new Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) for the period 2021-2027 and the European Fund for Reconstruction (ECI). After almost a record period of difficult political negotiations, a compromise has finally been reached that has managed to please all Member States. We can see as a great success the fact that, as the European Union, we continue to react promptly, jointly and ambitiously to emerge from the crisis together – stronger and more resilient to similar events in the future. A budget of EUR 1074 billion from the MFF and EUR 750 billion from the ECI is money that will serve our economies and citizens well in these difficult times. I believe that the key issue is now to adopt the budgetary provisions as soon as possible. As the compromise in the European Council is an excellent starting point, I call on Parliament to reach an agreement as soon as possible in order to be able to deliver resources to the eu's most deprived regions. I very much welcome the fact that cohesion policy has managed to defend it in the budgetary negotiations. Higher co-financing rates and a longer spending period are among the many improved conditions that will significantly improve the implementation process. I am also pleased that the least developed Polish will receive additional support of EUR 600 million compared to the one previously planned.

name: Łukasz Kohut (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "The old English saying says you can't eat a biscuit and have it. Perhaps since the British are not in the Community, somehow we are unwittingly trying for an EU version of this saying, only in an inverted formula – we try to have a cake and eat it, and still have it. At last year's European Council, EU leaders agreed that funding for the Just Transition Fund would be cut to €17.5 billion. This is more than twice as much as the €40 billion previously proposed. At the same time, they have maintained the objectives of climate neutrality, which we can only achieve if we carry out an effective energy transition. And it takes money to carry it out. A just transition is not only an expression of concern for those affected, it is also a question of pragmatism – those who feel harmed by change reject these changes. I understand that Member States want to save, but apparent savings are not savings. This is short-sighted politics. As the European Parliament, we cannot agree to it and we must fight for adequate funding for the Just Transition Fund.

name: Julie Lechanteux (ID)
text: In writing. The agreement on the post-Covid-19 recovery plan is far from the historic success announced by French President Emmanuel Macron, as it is the result of a haggling between the interests of the so-called frugal countries, the Eastern countries, the Franco-German couple and the countries of the South. The key word of this plan is debt! The 750 billion euro plan, which has been adopted, provides for 390 billion grants, thus non-refundable by its beneficiaries, and 360 billion in loans. Large sums that the EU, without its own resources, will have to borrow on the capital markets. Let us remember that the debt of the European Union is the debt of the Member States and especially of the net contributors to the European budget, which, like France, pay more than they receive. To be sure of advancing his Europeanist project, Macron has thus sacrificed France with an agreement that allows to advance a pernicious federalist agenda behind the backs of the people and at the expense of the French taxpayer. For if on the one hand France should receive 40 billion subsidies, on the other hand, it will participate in the repayment of this colossal new debt until 2058, with a considerable increase in its contribution to the EU budget.

name: Benoît Lutgen (PPE)
text: In writing. The agreement reached by the European Council blows the very hot and cold. The hot is the Recovery Plan: how it will be financed, the strong and welcome solidarity that is there, the support to the Member States that need it most.  The cold is the draft multi-year financial framework that gives us more than the impression that the Council has compensated for the generosity and strength of the Recovery Plan with incomprehensible cuts in the draft European budget in key strategic sectors such as agriculture or health whose resources are totally sufficient.  It is up to us European parliamentarians, in the coming weeks, to warm up this draft financial framework and to give it as much strength and ambition as the Recovery Plan.

name: Eva Maydell (PPE)
text: in writing. – With the Covid-19 pandemic far from being over in many EU Member States, its negative economic impact on public finances, businesses and employment is likely to deepen further. To mitigate these consequences the EU needs a swift and large-scale recovery plan. In this context I welcome the committed effort of European Council to come up with a political consensus on the way forward for the recovery. However, besides the imminent economic challenge, which Covid-19 presents, we must not lose sight of our strategic long-term objectives such as building a sustainable, socially fair and globally competitive EU economy based on science and innovations. The instrument we have to turn this ambitious vision into reality is our long-term EU budget. That is why I regret that the European Council missed the opportunity to enhance core EU programs that support R&D, digitalisation, education and just energy transition. These are proven investment instruments at EU level, which if are loaded with sufficient resources, could move our economy forward at a faster pace and support European companies to achieve global competitiveness in the next decades. I hope the negotiations on the MFF not only run swiftly, but also with a more forward-looking responsibility and ambition.

name: Leszek Miller (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I welcome the fact that the European Council has reached agreement on the EU budget 2021-2027 and the Reconstruction Fund. As a result, unprecedented measures (EUR 1.8 trillion) will be involved in the fight against the effects of the coronavirus pandemic in Europe.  However, the European Parliament should not unreflec reflexively accept all the findings of the Summit, as the community interest has been wrongly taken into account in the conclusions in order to achieve unanimity among the leaders of the Member States. Significant cuts have been made to health, youth, culture and education, research, the digital and ecological transformation of Europe. Moreover, contrary to the interests of Polish, funding for the transformation of coal-dependent regions and the development of rural regions has also been cut.  The scale of non-repayable grants to Member States under the Fund has also been significantly reduced by offering them loans in return. In this context, I believe that, in the interests of Polish and of Europe as a whole, we should in line with the demand for an increase in the amounts for these European programmes and for the establishment of new sources of EU own revenue (m.in. digital tax) so that it is not the Member States that have to bear the costs of recovering from the crisis in the long term. The need to solve economic problems must go hand in hand with the protection of the values on which the Union was built. In this context, I consider it an additional priority to establish an effective mechanism for linking EU funds to the protection of the EU's financial interests and the rule of law.

name: Janina Ochojska (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Thank you for all the efforts made in establishing the joint action plan and budget for the coming years. Having read the conclusions of the European Council, I would like to raise some reservations.  I cannot agree with the decision to reduce funding for health care, particularly now that the whole world is fighting the coronavirus epidemic and medical services in Europe need additional funding. Given the ageing trends of the population, people with disabilities and the ever-increasing number of cancer patients for whom access to modern medicine is crucial, additional funding is needed.  I also cannot support a significant reduction in funding for humanitarian and development aid to Africa. It has been said many times during the debates that the EU is not an ATM, which I fully understand. Compliance with the rule of law by The Member States is crucial for the further functioning of the Community, and it is therefore right to link it to funding in various economic and social fields.  Finally, I would just like to remind you that being a member of the EU is not only about reaping all sorts of benefits and privileges in this respect, but also about respecting the law and principles that guide the Community.

name: Sandra Pereira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The European Council meeting, conditioned and guided by the interests of the main beneficiaries of the integration process, highlighted the nature of the EU, which has generated inequalities, divergences and asymmetries, and whose only concern is capitalist competition in the single market, with no room for any solidarity between States. The Conclusions of the European Council set very unfavourable conditions for a country like Portugal. For example, there is a significant cut in the Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027 (at least in cohesion and agriculture), which is all the more serious as this Framework will be a reference for the future. And while Portugal will predictably increase its contribution to the EU budget, other countries (the Netherlands, Austria, Sweden, Denmark and also Germany), the main beneficiaries of the integration, guarantee a substantial increase in the discount to their contributions that they already benefited from. The Recovery Fund is also insufficient, particularly in its "grants" component, which has reduced from 500 to 390 billion. As the weight of the lending component will increase, there will also be greater indebtedness of states such as Portugal, which already face higher levels of indebtedness. In our view, all mechanisms that enshrine increased EU interference in the implementation of investment options and other sovereign decisions of the Member States should be rejected.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – Despite the protracted haggling, the conclusions of the European Council meeting have not delivered an appropriate and satisfactory European response to the economic crisis resulting from the corona virus pandemic and the multivariate strategies that the EU needs to follow in order not to lag too far behind the US and China. Beyond the economic and social divergences that have grown in recent years, the political divergences that define the European reality have now come into open display. In size and format, the Recovery Fund will likely not be enough to contain the as yet unforeseeable consequences of the pandemic. While the same remark applies to the MFF itself, the adjustments made to the latter so as to achieve a final agreement in Council seriously undermine the coherence of the EU budget. It is almost impossible to understand how and why areas like health, research and support to companies should be subjected to a brutal amputation. Unfortunately one doubts whether the intervention of this Parliament can in any way help to improve the situation. The only reason to support the agreement reached is because without any agreement at all, things would be much worse. That’s what we believe now. History might give a different verdict.

name: Sylwia Spurek (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – For me, the human rights defender, the former Deputy Ombudsman, the rule of law is one of the most important values of the European Community. At the same time, it is the foundation of all the democratic systems that make it complied with, which is necessary to ensure the protection of the rights of citizens and citizens of the Union.  However, a number of developments in recent years have exposed the weaknesses of EU control mechanisms and demonstrated how a lack of respect for common values and principles can lead to a situation where the rule of law is not given to us once and for all. I am an MEP from Polish, where for the last five years the ruling party has abolished the guarantees on the division of powers, destroyed judicial independence, violated the rights of women, LGBT+ people, disregarded the rights of persons with disabilities and the elderly. But we also have a problem with the rule of law in other Member States. And we have to fight for it.  The agreement adopted at the EU summit on linking the rule of law to EU funds offers hope for change. However, we must bear in mind that the effects of the introduction of this mechanism must not be directed at citizens and citizens. Sanctions must not hit those who do not condo no longer have their governments flouting the law. They must touch the actual perpetrators of the violations.

name: Bettina Vollath (S&D)
text: Writing. - EU leaders have reached an agreement on the Reconstruction Fund and the Multiannual Financial Framework. As much as Europe needs this quick agreement, the result is disappointing in the end. The total amount of grants is well below the proposals of the Commission and the European Parliament and thus does not do justice to the scale of the crisis. Not only has the scope of the reconstruction programme been cut, but the cuts to the rule of law, the Green Deal, health and research have turned an ambitious future programme into an inadequate "compromise." That is disappointing and I honestly say that we expected more. It is clear to me that we are in the biggest recession in EU history and that it would require much more than a minimum compromise. As the European Parliament, we must now show strength and call for renegotiation. With this resolution, we have a good basis for making it clear to the Council that now is not the time to wrestle with who is the least likely to help deal with the crisis, but on the contrary. When, if not now, is the time for joint ambitious European action? European citizens expect a Europe that lives up to its historical responsibilities. We must not disappoint them.

name: Alexandr Vondra (ECR)
text: Writing. – Colleagues from other parliamentary factions still did not understand the economic reality of today's EU. COVID-19 has hit the economies of individual countries in an unprecedented way, but members of the Socialists, Communists, People's Party, Greens and Renew Europe still want to burden European industry with further hard limits on CO2 emissions or by unifying direct taxes. At a time when millions of citizens are losing their jobs because of COVID-19, MEPs are demanding gender-balanced spending. All these demands go against the economic interests of our citizens and will translate into an increase in the price of energy and European products, such as cars. The result will be further redundancies and even higher unemployment.
